{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Muhyo & Roji’s Bureau: Is the Bellocent Incident Part of Enchu’s Plans?","link":"https://www.cbr.com/muhyo-rojis-bureau-season-2-episode-7-bellocent-incident-enchu-plans/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Teeki-Breaking-Through-Seal-Protection-Muhyos-Bureau-S2E7-1200.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for Season 2, Episode 7 of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/muhyo-rojis-bureau-of-supernatural-investigation/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Muhyo &#38; Roji's Bureau Of Supernatural Investigation</a>, \"Trust,\" now streaming on <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/sony-buy-crunchyroll-warnermedia-1-5-billion/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Crunchyroll</a>.</strong></em></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Enchu and his dark <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-why-wizards-makes-bad-cards/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">magic-wielding</a> allies have continued to lurk in the background of the second season of <em>Muhyo &#38; Roji’s Bureau Of Supernatural Investigation</em>. They've carried out some schemes, but seemingly haven't done much in the grand scheme. In place of direct actions, the situations with Muhyo summoning Hades and Roji undergoing Enforcer Page’s trial have taken the forefront of recent episodes. While they may not have had the spotlight, there is reason to believe that the Bellocent incident might be connected to Enchu’s plans.</span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The first thing to address is what Enchu and Teeki have been doing since their initial appearance. The events of the most recent episode link back to the fifth episode, where Enchu and Teeki infiltrate a bookstore which has connections to the Magic Association. After taking an older civilian hostage, they demand to know where the “genuine article” is from a younger worker. It’s clear that Enchu used his knowledge of Association-member identities to find this person. While the fate of this person is rather unclear, the result of this confrontation sets in motion their efforts.</span></p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/bleach-captain-tosen-zanpakuto-suzumushi-explained/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Bleach: Captain Tosen's Bloodless Zanpakuto, Suzumushi, Explained</a></span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The events leading to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/muhyo-rojis-bureau-season-2-episode-6/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Enforcer Page’s trial</a> start after this scene, hinting at the idea that Enchu and his associates discovered the location of this “genuine article” before the test could begin. From that moment in the bookstore, Teeki and Enchu seem to go different ways. While Enchu is walking in a city-like area, Teeki is eerily close to Magic Law Academy. He moves through the scenes as a dark shadow illuminated by the storm as people try to get explosive equipment so that Page can get inside.</span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Teeki-Illuminated-By-Lightning-Muhyos-Bureau-S2E6-1200.jpg\"/></figure><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Bellocent has already wreaked havoc inside the academy, attacking several weaker students and engaging in a battle with Roji’s crew. With these students occupied on the inside and those on the outside trying to break in to save them, this creates a perfect distraction that forces a lot of association members to that one area.</span></p><p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Conveniently, while they’re preoccupied with this mission, Teeki strikes. He infiltrates a building from the roof, entering a building with a room that is protected by a magic barrier. While touching it triggers a reaction, Teeki approaches it and sticks a hand through to the other side. By going through this barrier, Teeki is able to grab a forbidden <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/bakemonogatari-manga-differences-light-novels-anime/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">book </a>that seems to share a personal connection with him. After this relatively easy break-in, Teeki flees the scene with this special book.</span></p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/hunter-x-hunter-gon-killua-not-rivals-better-for-it/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hunter X Hunter: Gon &#38; Killua Aren't Rivals - and Are Better for It</a></span></p><p>It seems fairly likely that the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/muhyo-rojis-bureau-bellocent-met-his-match/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Bellocent attack </a>was coordinated with Enchu's group. Even if they didn't speak with Bellocent directly, they could have had knowledge of Bellocent's escape attempt. After all, the theft of this book occurs at the right time where everyone else is distracted.</p><p>This wouldn't be the first time that they carried out a scheme using other spirits. The arc where Muhyo and Roji entered a spirit containment center and fought an unrestrained Sophie was orchestrated by Enchu and Teeki, who waited in the background to see if Sophie could actually kill them. When this plan ended in failure, Teeki was able to use all the detained spirits in order to create a monstrous amalgamation.</p><p>The speculation regarding the situation surrounding this scheme only leaves the question of what they are planning to use it for. It's very clear that Enchu has his gripes with the Magic Association, and now that Teeki has this book he will likely be able to draw on stronger forces using it. With this loss, members of the Magic Association are going to have an even rougher time handling Enchu's dark magic users.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/certain-scientific-railgun-t-episode-19-unlikely-friendship-develops/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A Certain Scientific Railgun T: An Unlikely Friendship Develops</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 19:45:23 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Teeki-Breaking-Through-Seal-Protection-Muhyos-Bureau-S2E7-1200.jpg","linkMd5":"8451ac7051c5af9f8b4e408c29967408","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn44@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-11-328_1dda404dc0e5524b.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":52542,"destBytes":52542,"author":"Michael Collado","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Teeki-Breaking-Through-Seal-Protection-Muhyos-Bureau-S2E7-1200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn44@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-11-328_1dda404dc0e5524b.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Teeki-Illuminated-By-Lightning-Muhyos-Bureau-S2E6-1200.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-22-375_83103b9e32bb36b4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389172},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Mass Effect: Andromeda - The Training Classes, Explained | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-andromeda-training-classes-explained/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Mass-Effect-Andromedas-training-classes-give-you-a-head-start.jpg\"/></figure><p>BioWare's <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/mass-effect/\">Mass Effect</a> </em>series blends intense action and deep roleplaying, allowing players to choose how they want to play. The games in the original trilogy feature six classes, each of which either specializes in or combines combat, technology and biotic abilities. These classes can drastically affect the way a player experiences <em>Mass Effect, </em>as well as changing which team members work well in a group.</p><p><em>Mass Effect: Andromeda </em>uses a similar system, but the classes are now known as profiles. Rather than being stuck in one class like in previous games, protagonist Ryder can unlock additional profiles and then switch between them during gameplay.</p><p>However, players are asked to choose a training class during character creation, which will determine their abilities and skills for the first several hours of gameplay. For veterans and new players alike, here is a breakdown of <em>Andromeda</em>'s six training classes.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-commander-shepard-rachni-queen/\">Mass Effect: How Shepard Decided the Rachni Queen's Fate on Noveria</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-security.png\"/></figure><p><em>Andromeda</em>'s Security training class corresponds to the Soldier class found in previous <em>Mass Effect </em>games. It focuses on the use of weapons, making it the most basic \"third-person shooter\" class as it grants powers to improve Ryder's ability to both dish out and take damage.</p><p>Players who choose Security training won't have tech or biotic abilities to fall back on, so they should take advantage of the Combat Fitness passive ability, which allows them to carry more weapons. The Concussive Shot power is useful for stunning dangerous enemies, while the Turbocharge buff is great for chipping away at a particularly armored opponent.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-biotic.png\"/></figure><p>The Biotic training class corresponds to the Adept profile, which focuses on the use of powerful energy attacks. Biotics are great at controlling the flow of combat, using their powers to disrupt enemy attacks and positions. Throw lets players toss an enemy into the air, leaving them completely exposed to attacks. Singularity also disables enemies, trapping them in a vortex, while Barrier enhances Ryder's armor and makes them much more durable.</p><p>Biotic players should pick their squadmates carefully, choosing characters who will be able to capitalize on the opening created by their powers, and pay attention to enemy movements.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-samara-justicar-revealed/\">Mass Effect: The Life of Samara the Justicar, Revealed</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-technician.png\"/></figure><p>Technicians, roughly analogous to Engineers, make for an excellent support system on the battlefield. Their abilities focus almost exclusively on buffing allies and debuffing enemies, meaning their teammates will be doing most of the physical damage.</p><p>The Overload power does tons of damage to shields and synthetics, while Invasion hacks enemies and drastically lowers their defenses. Team Support, meanwhile, increases the entire team's shields. A good Technician should have their eye on their teammates at all times, so they known when best to let those powers loose.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-leader.jpg\"/></figure><p>Leader training sets <em>Mass Effect: Andromeda </em>players on the path of the Sentinel, in a class which combines technology and biotics. Leaders have access to Energy Drain -- a power that replenishes their own shields by draining health from enemies -- as well as Team Support. Annihilation, a biotic power which deals damage to nearby enemies, can also act as a combo primer by dealing massive damage if another biotic power is used at the same time.</p><p>By increasing their squad's shields and setting up powerful combo attacks, the Leader is perhaps the best class for players who enjoy working with their teammates.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-the-asari-explained/\">Mass Effect: The Asari, Explained</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-scrapper.png\"/></figure><p>The Scrapper, like the Vanguard class that it unlocks, combines combat and biotic skills to become a close-range powerhouse.</p><p>The Scrapper can use Charge, which turns them into pure energy and sends them slamming into an enemy, to recharge their shields and instantly get in enemies' faces. They also have the Combat Fitness passive ability, which increases their durability and lets them carry additional weapons. Both of these abilities make the Scrapper a perfect fit for players who want to zip around the battlefield and deal some intense close-range damage.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-operative.jpg\"/></figure><p>The final training class is the Operative, which corresponds to the Infiltrator class by mixing tech and combat abilities. The Operative is a stealth class, which uses subterfuge and tactical placement to thrive in combat. Like Security and Scrappers, Operatives also have Combat Fitness, which lets them take more damage and carry more weapons than other classes.</p><p>However, their main tool is Tactical Cloak, a power which allows them to briefly become invisible to enemies and freely reposition themselves on the battlefield. Attacking will instantly break the cloaking effect, but this attack will also gain a large boost in damage, so Operatives should plan their moves accordingly. Operatives make great solo agents, especially when paired with allies who can effectively draw enemy fire.</p><p><em>Mass Effect: Andromeda </em>made a number of changes to the series' typical gameplay, such as adding a jetpack for maneuverability and making each planet its own open-world. The ability to switch freely between different profiles is another big change, and one that allows players to more freely experiment with the game's many options. Still, training classes allow players to determine their abilities early in the game and let them decide what role they want to play in its treacherous battles.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Keep Reading: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-jack-mighty-biotic-life-explained/\">Mass Effect: The Life of Jack the Mighty Biotic, Explained</a></span></p>\n                        \n +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Mass-Effect-Andromedas-training-classes-give-you-a-head-start.jpg","linkMd5":"edccc0d9f6dc7a30febde511cbe7a5c8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn8@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-09-352_43044475d73069bf.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":96490,"destBytes":96490,"author":"Thomas McNulty","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Mass-Effect-Andromedas-training-classes-give-you-a-head-start.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn8@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-09-352_43044475d73069bf.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-security.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn63@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-21-111_01b30009ed0d77d2.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-biotic.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-25-330_21871e2eb59a247f.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-technician.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-31-547_87301b9d4498e6d9.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-leader.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn43@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-21-249_8e3e09c45d7059bc.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-scrapper.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn4@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-21-260_0c8dc38ad72e9178.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-andromeda-operative.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn7@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-31-693_6c121b71ffc863c3.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389182},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Batman: How the Dark Knight Discovered the Three Jokers | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/batman-discovered-three-jokers/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-Three-Jokers-feature.jpg\"/></figure><p>There are a lot of Jokers running around the DC Universe right now. At the moment, the Batman Who Laughs -- a Jokerized Batman -- is trying to rewrite the multiverse in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dark-nights-death-metal\"><em>Dark Nights: Death Metal</em>,</a> while the standard Joker holds complete control of Gotham City  and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-joker-war-blackest-night/\">its dead</a>, after taking everything away from Batman in \"Joker War.\" Now, even more Jokers are set to invade with the release of <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/three-jokers/\">Batman: Three Jokers</a></em> #1, written by Geoff Johns and drawn by Jason Fabok.</p><p>After being teased since the final days of the New 52 era, <em>Three Jokers </em>is set to reveal more about the three individuals who have served as the Joker during some of Gotham's most pivotal moments. Since this enigma has remained unanswered for so long, let's look at how Batman even learned that his greatest foe wasn't just one individual.</p><p>This mystery's origin was found in the midst of \"Darkseid War,\" the finale to Geoff Johns and Jason Fabok's <em>Justice League</em> run during the New 52. When the Justice League found themselves embroiled in a war between Darkseid's Apokolips forces and the Anti-Monitor, who was joined by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/darkseid-daughter-grail-explainer/\">the daughter of Darkseid,</a> the heroes were desperate for answers on how to put an end to this conflict. After being boom-tubed out of battle by Metron, the heroes were unwilling to play<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-new-gods-film/\"> the New God</a>'s usual game of doom-saying warnings and cryptic answers. Using the Lasso of Truth, Wonder Woman learned that the only way to get a clear solution to their problem was to take the Mobius Chair from him. After accomplishing this, the chair nearly departed from them before Batman took a seat on the alien relic and became possessed by it.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/joker-war-batman-arkham-games-cues/\">Joker War Takes TERRIFYING Cues from Batman: Arkham Games</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/bat.jpg\"/></figure><p>The Mobius Chair has always served as one of the most powerful items tied to the cosmic side of the DC universe. Since its introduction in Jack Kirby's <em>New Gods</em>, the Mobius-created chair has proven itself to be virtually untouchable to most powers throughout the multiverse. Allowing its user to travel anywhere through time and space, the Mobius Chair has become a source of limitless knowledge and secrets after all of its many travels. Its wielders are transformed upon connecting to the chair, causing them to become callous to those around them.</p><p>After taking a seat, the first question Batman asked was for the name of the man that killed his parents. When the chair provided him with the answer of Joe Chill, which he already knew, Batman then proceeded to ask the Mobius Chair for the identity of the Joker. At first, the answer remained hidden with Batman only expressing disbelief and confusion before returning to the matters at hand. It wasn't until the end of the battle with Darkseid and the Anti-Monitor -- after he gave up the Mobius Chair -- that Batman revealed the answer the chair had given to him. While talking to Hal Jordan within the Batcave, Batman answered that the chair did not respond with a name, but simply said that there were three Jokers.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-three-jokers-artist-fabok-every-variant-cover-process/\">Batman: Three Jokers Artist Breaks Down the Process Behind Every Variant Cover</a></span></p><p><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Three-Jokers.jpg\" /></p><p>As seen in both <em>Justice League</em> and the <em>DC Universe: Rebirth</em> one-shot, it seemed that each of these three Jokers was tied to an era of Batman stories. As <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-jason-fabok-reveals-names-dcs-three-jokers/\">Fabok revealed,</a> the first of these is a criminal mastermind whose most similar to the Golden Age Joker. He's joined by the\" Clownish Joker,\" who pulled off ridiculous gags in the Silver Age of Comics. This trio is rounded out by the \"Comedian Joker,\" the psychotic killer from comics like <em>Batman: The Killing Joke</em></p><p>During the course of \"Darkseid War\", the members of the Justice League each learned massive secrets about their past and future. However, the revelation of multiple Jokers completely changed the dynamic between Batman and his greatest enemy. Now, he understood that the undertaking of the Joker was never limited to one man. While the Mobius Chair went on to be wielded by characters like Wally West in the lead-up to <em>Death Metal, Three Jokers </em>seems set to answer questions that have puzzled both Batman and DC fans for years.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-three-jokers-ending-massive-effect-dcu-if-dc-allows/\">Batman: Three Jokers' Ending Will Have a MASSIVE Effect on the DCU - If DC Allows It</a></span></p><p><!-- Used for easily cloning the properly namespaced rect --></p><p><!-- Used for easily cloning the properly namespaced rect --></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 12:20:13 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-Three-Jokers-feature.jpg","linkMd5":"3136bff323e6763573d77bc9e6db2b6a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn20@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-10-399_4e9aed5f91d1d2f5.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":213466,"destBytes":173314,"author":"Paul Yang","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-Three-Jokers-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn20@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-10-399_4e9aed5f91d1d2f5.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/bat.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn63@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-31-247_0bdde6f5d1ddc5dd.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Three-Jokers.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-30-793_52775984c174df3b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389184},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"The VERY FIRST What If...? Comic Book Story, Revisited | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/batman-first-what-if-comic-book-story/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/what-if-batman-display.jpg\"/></figure><p>In <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/when-we-first-met/\" target=\"_blank\">\"When We First Met\"</a>, we spotlight the various characters, phrases, objects or events that eventually became notable parts of comic lore, like the first time someone said, \"Avengers Assemble!\" or the first appearance of Batman's giant penny or the first appearance of Alfred Pennyworth or the first time Spider-Man's face was shown half-Spidey/half-Peter. Stuff like that.</p><p>Today, based on a suggestion from my pal, <a href=\"https://dangermart.blog/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow\">Martin Gray</a>, we look at when the first \"What If?\" comic book story debuted.</p><p>At its simplest form, you have to realize that \"What If?\" is one of the fundamental driving forces of all fiction. Pretty much everything that has ever happened in any sort of media has revolved around the idea, \"What If....something?\" For instance, \"What if an alien lands on Earth as a baby and has superpowers?\" \"What if we turned the Shadow into a superhero who likes bats?\" So really, almost EVERY comic book, under a certain theory, would count as a What If? story. But obviously that's not what Martin is looking for here. We're talking about a comic book story where the \"What If...?\" idea is specifically part of the comic in an open fashion.</p><p>Along those lines, then, I would have to discount the frequent usage of the term \"What If?\" in humor comic books, with Mad Magazine's first usage occurring in 1958's Mad #42, \"What If You Did What They Told You On TV?\" </p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mad-42-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>This occurred a lot in humor comics of the era. In this instance (by writers Dee Caruso and Bill Levine and artist Bob Clarke), it was a simple case of imagining what would happen if you actually tried to do the things that they told you to do in commercials. Really basic stuff, but that was the driving force of a number of similar gags in other humor comics from this era (both Mad and its various copycat competitors). Just a general, \"Hey, what if this happened?\" </p><p>So, if you're looking for the first comic book story that actively worked \"What If?\" into the feature, then this would be the answer, but again, I assume we're specifically talking about a comic book where it is an alternate reality centered around asking \"What If?,\" right? </p><p>In other words, something like Archie and Me #9's \"What If?\" by Bob Bolling and Jon D'Agostino, where Mister Weatherbee wonders what it would be like if Archie was his son...</p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/archie-and-me-9-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>Naturally, it would not have turned out well, and by the end of his wondering about the scenario, Weatherbee keeps thinking of how bad Archie would be as a son that he ends up yelling at Archie for no reason when he next runs into him. That 1966 story would be precisely what Martin is looking for, but sadly (okay, \"sadly\" is a stretch, but when an answer is predictable, it is kind of sad for me), the answer is precisely the story that Martin thought it would be when he wrote in to me. He asked if 1965's Detective Comics #347 was really the first and it looks like it was, in fact, the first \"What If?\" story in comics (where the \"What If?\" suggests an alternate reality story). </p><p>The lead feature in Detective #347 was written by Gardner Fox and drawn by Carmine Infantino and Joe Giella and it dealt with a brand-new villain known as the Bouncer. The Bouncer had an elastic costume that allowed him to bounce all over the place, but he also had weapons made out of the same special elastic material, so he had a gun, for instance, that he could bounce off of a wall and have it fire. </p><p>Batman and Robin, though, realize that if they freeze his costume and his gun, it can remove the elasticity from them both, so when the Bouncer goes to throw his gun to bounce off of a wall and fire on Batman, it instead breaks on the wall and Batman knocks him out cold. That, of course, is how the story OFFICIALLY ended.</p><p>This, though, then led to a special detour where Gardner Fox took readers into his own home and show them his \"What IF?\" room. This is the place where he goes to think about stories that he has just completed and debate how the story could have taken a drastic turn depending on different circumstances. He then decided to show one such alternate scenario to the readers. </p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/detective-comics-347-3.jpg\"/></figure><p>This time around, the Bouncer quickly figured out what Batman and Robin were trying to do. In the original story, Batman stalls him long enough for the freezing effect to take control. Here, though, since the Bouncer cops to their plan, he makes his move sooner, and throws his elastic gun before it can be frozen and it does its trick and it bounces off of the wall and fires upon Batman, killing the Dark Knight in cold blood (but not cold enough to freeze elastic material).</p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/detective-comics-347-4.jpg\"/></figure><p>Fox then shows the Justice League come to pay tribute to their fallen comrade and Robin vows revenge on the Bouncer. This time around, since the gun trick worked, the gun was left behind as evidence and Robin was able to experiment on it and discover a way to use elastic fatigue to break down the Bouncer's elasticity in a different fashion. When they fought against each other, Robin was able to win and arrest Batman's killer.</p><p>However, then Batman shows ups...alive! It turns out that the Earth-2 Batman found out about what happened to his Earth-1 counterpart and decided to travel to Earth-1 to take over his fallen counterpart. Earth-2 Batman was older, and nearing retirement on Earth-2 anyways. In addition, Earth-2 Batman brought along Earth-2 Alfred to help cheer Robin up, as Earth-1 Alfred had been killed a year or so earlier. </p><p>The issue ended with readers being asked if they wanted to see more of these \"What If?\" stories. However, soon after this, the Batman TV series debuted, and Fox and the other Batman writers had to spend their time writing stories similar to the TV series and the \"What If...?\" approach was forgotten (or maybe fans wrote in and said they didn't want it. I doubt it, though). </p><p>Thanks for the suggestion, Martin!</p><p>If anyone else has a suggestion for/question about a notable comic book first, drop me a line at brianc@cbr.com!</p>\n +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/what-if-batman-display.jpg","linkMd5":"ea99045f1e19176af858aa6936f3071f","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn35@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-341_5fa807c692523f33.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":170564,"destBytes":170564,"author":"Brian Cronin","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/what-if-batman-display.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn35@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-341_5fa807c692523f33.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mad-42-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn20@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-26-980_050436d5d3b487b8.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/archie-and-me-9-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-29-026_1f77f5ae88e78040.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/detective-comics-347-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-22-923_419aadfd2dc40413.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/detective-comics-347-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn47@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-22-322_6721c7fc9fc5510f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389176},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Horizon Zero Dawn #1: The Carja Hunters Lodge Is in Disarray","link":"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-carja-hunters-lodge-disarray/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/horizon-zero-dawn-comic.jpg\"/></figure><p><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for Titan Comics' <em>Horizon Zero Dawn #1</em> from Anne Toole and Ann Maulina, available now.</strong></p><p>The excitement around the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/horizon-zero-dawn/\"><em>Horizon Zero Dawn</em></a> franchise is at an all-time high. The game's sequel, <em>Horizon Forbidden West</em>, has been <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/sony-horizon-forbidden-west-playstation-5-trailer/\">confirmed for PlayStation 5</a>, and the 2017 original j<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-pc-trailer-release-date/\">ust landed on PC</a>. The franchise is now expanding beyond the realm of games with a run from <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-comic-book-adaptation-titan/\">Titan Comics</a>.</p><p>The first issue offers a tantalizing expansion to Horizon's lore, such as one revelation about the Carja Hunters Lodge. While this noble institution once stood tall, we see it somewhat disheveled in issue one.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-1-review/\">Horizon Zero Dawn #1 is a Serviceable, if Uneven Continuation of the Game</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/HZD1.jpg\"/></figure><p>Central to this new tension is Talanah Khane Padish, the Sunhawk of the Hunters Lodge. The Sunhawk is the leader of the Lodge, a cultural totem that attracts all manner of Carja hunters. Based on tradition, the Hunter's Lodge is a deeply revered and sacred part of Carja culture and history. However, it is also one marred by outdated sensibilities – including bigotry against women. Talanah worked to overturn that and instill progressive sentiments into the Hunters Lodge by winning the position of Sunhawk. She accomplished this with the help of Aloy when the two defeated a domineering Thunderjaw whom the Hunters Lodge dubbed Redmaw.</p><p>This leads us to issue one, where we find Talanah back on the hunt in an attempt to clear her mind the only way she knows how. We learn that she has been training a new generation of hunters, including the headstrong and reckless Kyran. Deeming the Clawstrider too dangerous, Talanah denies Kyran the contract and takes it on herself. After being injured in her fight and nursed back to health by the mysterious Amadis, Talanah sees Kyran attempting the same bounty.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-outcast-aloy-title-seeker/\">Horizon Zero Dawn: How the Outcast Aloy Earned the Title of Seeker</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/horizon-zero-dawn-1-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>His disobedience serves as an elegant microcosm for the issues facing the Hunters Lodge. Kyran not only ignored a direct command from the Sunhawk, but he also hired a band of mercenaries to assist him in the felling the beast. Kyran's bungling of the situation continues when he slays the incorrect machine and leaves its corpse behind, an action that put a young boy in danger. The sense of elegance, respect and discipline characteristic of the Hunters Lodge is absent from Kyran's actions.</p><p>With only one issue currently available, it is unclear exactly what the stem of the problem is. However, Amadis alludes to the potential that it is attributed in some part to Talanah being a woman. As the two argue about Kyran's actions, Amadis remarks, \"the Lodge makes you feel special. First woman to join? Yeah, they convinced you it was an honor to sweep up after them.\" Due to the longstanding biases and historical patterns in the Hunters Lodge, Talanah's femininity could be one cause of this tension.</p><p>However, Talanah's courage against Redmaw and her ability to take the position of Sunhawk have shown her unmatched courage and skill. Undoubtedly, future issues will show her regaining control of the Hunters Lodge while coming to terms with her leadership. The Hunters Lodge and the Carja society are some of Horizon's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-lore-reveals-about-sequel/\">most interesting lore elements</a>, and it will be tantalizing to learn more about these as the narrative progresses. We will not have to wait long to see Talanah's story continue, though, as <em>Horizon Zero Dawn</em> #2 will be available on September 2nd.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/horizon-zero-dawn-hades-supercomputer-explained/\">Horizon Zero Dawn: HADES, the World-Ending Supercomputer, Explained</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 12:15:07 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/horizon-zero-dawn-comic.jpg","linkMd5":"876934f72a24791a6ef1f57989fcb192","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-09-445_b2c1793270c6d627.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":159386,"destBytes":159386,"author":"Abram Buehner","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/horizon-zero-dawn-comic.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-09-445_b2c1793270c6d627.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/HZD1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn27@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-26-983_5ed7fae31233d8d0.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/horizon-zero-dawn-1-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn23@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-28-524_d3c5b3eb10cb5b66.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389184},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Ocarina of Time & Other Titles Rely On Music - But Accessibility Is An Issue","link":"https://www.cbr.com/legend-zelda-ocarina-time-music-accessibility/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Zelda-Song.jpg\"/></figure><p>Music has long been a huge and welcome part of video games. From standout soundtracks from games like <em>Journey</em> to rhythm games like <em>Rock Band</em>, there are so many ways that music finds its way into games. A stellar game soundtrack instills a lot of love for classic games and is one of the things gamers can connect to on a deeply emotional level, no matter the genre.</p><p>One of the most interesting ways music is utilized, however, is as a mechanic. <em>Loom</em> and <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/legend-of-zelda/\">The Legend of Zelda</a>: Ocarina of Time</em> showcase the wildly interesting yet often unsuccessful and problematic ways that video games have used music as a mechanic.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tales-monkey-island-returns-steam/\">Tales Of Monkey Island Is Back - Here's What You Should Know</a></span></p><p>In 1990, the same year Lucasfilm Games released the well-known <em>Monkey Island</em>, it also released the much smaller and more obscure game, <em>Loom</em>. Set in a fantasy world, <em>Loom </em>tells a lackluster story relying on substantial character knowledge that the player doesn't have a lot of exposition on in the final moments. Where <em>Loom</em> may let players down as a narrative, it offers up an intriguing mechanic for an old-school adventure game. Players might be used to a small vocabulary to define how they can interact with the game world — \"pickup,\" \"walk,\" \"talk,\" etc. — but in <em>Loom,</em> the vocabulary isn't words, but instead small melodies.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Loom-Screenshots.jpg\"/></figure><p>Players change the world of <em>Loom</em> by playing these melodies on a magical staff, with lower notes on the left end and higher notes on the right. The four notes that allow them to dye a bunch of wool grass green allows the player to dye a flock of sheep, hiding them from an approaching dragon. Most interestingly, playing the melody in reverse undoes the action; a song that twists up a water spout will untwist it when played in reverse, and one that spins straw into gold can turn a dragon's horde into flammable straw.</p><p>The music in Loom shows a novel way of thinking about how players can interact with the in-game world, but the melodies are unfortunately uninteresting. It may even be a stretch to call the four-note themes \"music.\" It's a fun exploration, but ultimately one that's unsuccessful.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fuser-demo-impressions/\">Fuser Demo: Harmonix's New Rhythm Game Offers Freedom, Music And Corgis</a></span></p><p>Perhaps the most well-known example of music as a mechanic is <em>The Legend of</em> <em>Zelda</em> series. <em>Ocarina of Time </em>is a beloved classic that features many truly novel mechanics beyond just the addition of music. Unlike <em>Loom</em>, though, it also features a lovely and memorable story.</p><p>In addition to wielding a sword and bow, Link brandishes the titular ocarina. While players will solve pathfinding puzzles and fight bosses, part of the game also involves playing the right song at the right time. Some of the songs are just for gaining access to a temple, while others have utility within gameplay, such as summoning a player's horse or freezing undead enemies. The player interacts with the rest of the world much like in other games, though, with the game's verbs of \"walk\" and \"fight\" linked to regular buttons.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/video-game-food-recipe-resources/\">Food For Gamers: The 8 Best Places To Find Video Game Recipes</a></span></p><p><em>Ocarina of Time</em> and other <em>Legend of Zelda</em> games succeed where <em>Loom</em> fails because they add music-playing to the standard game mechanics, rather than replacing them. While this replacement gave <em>Loom</em> a truly novel feel, it also made the game's controls unintuitive and frustrating. Both of these games, however, demonstrate the potential value of using these aural cues as truly integral game components.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Legend-of-Zelda-Ocarina.jpg\"/></figure><p>Linking the mechanics of a game to sound can pose some problems for accessibility. For the deaf and hard of hearing communities, this aspect of the games can be entirely unapproachable. Without accompanying visual cues, sound alone is not a usable mechanic.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/cadence-of-hyrule-give-indie-made-zelda-game-a-chance/\">Cadence Of Hyrule: Why You Should Give This Indie-Made Zelda Game A Chance</a></span></p><p><em>Loom</em> attempts to counter this through the visual component of the music-making staff. Not only are notes located in different physical spaces on the staff, but when clicked, they glow a different color. However, while this may allow players to reproduce a tune based on location or color and not sound, it reduces the melody-based mechanic to visual patterns.</p><p><em>Ocarina of Time</em> tries to make its musical mechanic more accessible than <em>Loom</em>. Notes are presented on a musical staff, but no knowledge of how to formally read music is required. Instead, the notes are color-coded and labeled according to the controller's buttons. Such notation means that the songs in <em>Ocarina of Time</em> can be played even if they can't be heard, but only add additional aural information for players familiar with this notation.</p><p>Experimentation with music as an integral game component presents players and developers alike with a whole new range of interface options and gameplay cues. Yet when implemented without due consideration, it can make games inaccessible. These novel mechanics can make gameplay incredibly interesting, but it's important that they're interesting for everybody.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Keep Reading: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/text-based-adventure-games-modern-world/\">Four Text-Based Adventure Games That Modernize The Genre</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 14:15:23 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Zelda-Song.jpg","linkMd5":"edf258945447064ab5b0faf46be96836","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-10-543_ccc6750011a5f496.webp","destWidth":1366,"destHeight":683,"sourceBytes":65176,"destBytes":65176,"author":"E.L. Meszaros","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Zelda-Song.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-10-543_ccc6750011a5f496.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Loom-Screenshots.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-21-290_8356e25690ad7e74.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Legend-of-Zelda-Ocarina.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-23-606_701acb68b715a95a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389191},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Todd McFarlane Designs a New Batman for DC Multiverse Toy Line","link":"https://www.cbr.com/mcfarlane-toys-batman-dc-multiverse/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mcfarlane-batman-header.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/mcfarlane-toys/\">McFarlane Toys</a> has debuted a brand-new <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/batman/\">Batman</a> action figured designed by Todd McFarlane himself for the DC Multiverse toy line.</p><p>McFarlane Toys' official press release is below:</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"A Major Batman Villain Got Called Out for Why They're REALLY a Monster\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-killer-croc-monster/\">A Major Batman Villain Got Called Out For Why They're REALLY A Monster</a></span></p><p><em>Tempe, Ariz., August 24, 2020– Todd McFarlane, one of the most iconic comic book artists of the late 20th century, has unveiled a brand-new DC Multiverse Batman action figure designed, created and produced by McFarlane and his award-winning McFarlane Toys company.</em></p><p><em>This new Batman action figure is inspired from the mind of Todd McFarlane. McFarlane has created a new never-before-seen before version of Batman’s costume. It features a Black Cape and Cowl, comes with two swords, a base, and includes a collectible art card with Todd McFarlane's Batman artwork on front and character biography on the back. The incredibly detailed 7-inch scale figure is designed with McFarlane Toys' signature \"Ultra Articulation\" with up to 22 moving parts for a full range of posing and play.</em></p><p><em>In the 1980s, Todd McFarlane began drawing Batman professionally, working on the classic storyline \"Batman: Year Two™\" in Detective Comics™, and creating iconic artwork, including his dynamic cover for Batman #423. Todd went on to become a titan of the comic book industry but has always had an affinity for Batman.</em></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-by-T.-McFarlane.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-by-T.-McFarlane2.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>\"Batman has always been my favorite character- excluding Spawn,\" said McFarlane, creative force and CEO of McFarlane Toys. \"I've always liked the fact that Batman has no superpowers. When it comes down to it, he's just a dude in a costume trying to combat evil. Conceivably, if Batman were in a huge battle in space, without any of his gadgets and tech, he could potentially die, unlike Superman™. I've always had an affinity for Batman, and it’s an honor to design a brand new version of a Batman figure for all fans and collectors.\"</em></p><p><em>McFarlane Toys is also bringing collectors and fans a brand-new collector program. With the launch of the new Batman figure by Todd McFarlane, McFarlane Toys has announced its new McFarlane Gold Label Collection Series that will feature characters from your favorite pop-culture and entertainment brands. All figures released in the McFarlane Gold Label Collection will be highly limited and showcased in limited- edition packaging with a McFarlane Toys Gold Label Collection printed in foil. Look for more McFarlane Toys Collector Series announcement coming soon.</em></p><p><em>The McFarlane Gold Label Collection Batman by Todd McFarlane figure will be available for pre-order in mid-Oct at <a href=\"http://walmart.com/\">Walmart.com</a>. The figure is exclusive to Walmart but will be available at select international specialty retailers. The retailer release date is January 2021. MSRP $19.99</em></p><p><em>For more information, get connected to McFarlane! Follow Us!</em></p><p><em>Instagram: <a href=\"https://mcfarlane.us8.list-manage.com/track/click?u=e7f2aab0d2271b5c5290a2b77&#38;id=054231250c&#38;e=f92c10df3b\">https://www.instagram.com/mcfarlane_toys_official/</a></em></p><p><em>Twitter Gets Geralt Of Rivia Action Figure From McFarlane Toys</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:55:35 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mcfarlane-batman-header.jpg","linkMd5":"662cdbf9c8f11f078522a306931767a8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn71@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-10-555_01dfe8948e04cdd0.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":53186,"destBytes":51740,"author":"Jon Arvedon","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mcfarlane-batman-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn71@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-10-555_01dfe8948e04cdd0.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-by-T.-McFarlane.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn28@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-29-557_bdb2f458672d9da9.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Batman-by-T.-McFarlane2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-26-925_5a30d81d81c32150.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389168},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Deca-Dence: Kaburagi Starts a New Game (In a New Body) | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/deca-dence-episode-7-kaburagi-new-game-new-body/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-kaburagi-episode-7.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for Episode 7 of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/deca-dence/\">Deca-Dence</a>, \"Driveshaft,\" now streaming on Funimation. </strong></em></p><p>After gaining access to a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/deca-dence-episode-2-huge-twist/\">pirated version of the game</a> and beaming out of purgatory, Kaburagi is officially back. Because logging into his old account would raise the alarm, the veteran player has to start a new game, and this means (as fans speculated) creating a new avatar. He doesn't waste any time prettying it up: the finished product looks like his old avatar with slightly longer hair and an unfortunate color palette. Then again, Kaburagi clearly isn't one to care about appearances, and all he wants to do is get in contact with Natsume as quickly as possible.</p><p>During his <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/deca-dence-spoiler-makes-the-ultimate-sacrifice-natsumi-kaburagi/\">supposed death</a>, things have gotten worse for the humans of Deca-Dence. The fortress has been overrun with Gadoll, specifically (and suspiciously) targeting the clustered city that the Tankers call home. Kaburagi helps fend the monsters off, but he's a bit clumsy. Understandably, fighting in a different avatar takes a bit of getting used to, even if it seems his skills have transferred over.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lapis-relights-episode-7-maryberry-performance-tiara-orchestra-plan/\">Lapis Re:LIGHTs: Maryberry's Performance Sparks Tiara's Orchestra Plan</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-kaburagi-new-avatar.jpg\"/></figure><p>Thankfully, a Gadoll that slips away from Kaburagi is put down by Natsume, who heroically saves a crowd of Tankers. Natsume appears to be doing just fine without her mentor around, though she's too busy for Kaburagi to confront her right away.</p><p>Before talking to Natsume, Kaburagi decides to pay a visit to Minato, the Deca-Dence Commander in Chief. As suspected, Minato explains that the current Gadoll onslaught is meant to cut back on the Tanker population. Apparently, the Tankers are expanding too quickly, and Solid Quake is using the Gadoll as a means to make the fortress more manageable. Minato doesn't have a problem with this, and he doesn't understand why Kaburgai cares about the lives of humans. However, he's also the reason Kaburagi wasn't scrapped after rebelling, so he's a good guy deep down.</p><p>Meanwhile, Natsume is doing it all. She fights off the invading Gadoll, comes up with ideas to patch up the busted fortress and rallies the Tankers into action all before the sun goes down. Kaburagi watches from afar, still (after seven episodes) unable to fathom how Natsume can work so hard in a situation so dire. Eventually, he approaches the girl, though he doesn't let her in on his real identity. He says he was sent by Kaburagi, and the two sit down to talk.</p><p>Kaburagi discovers that Natsume isn't doing too well after all. She's struggling with the pressure and understandably overwhelmed by the situation, which keeps getting worse and worse. With everyone banding together, the Tankers did end up fixing the fortress, but Kaburagi knows the Gadoll attacks will never end. Solid Quake will not let up, dwindling down the Tanker population until they're satisfied. The system is <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/deca-dence-kurenai-stars-in-subterranean-battle/\">unwinnable by design</a>. Not for the first time, reflecting on Nastume's predicament affects Kaburagi greatly. His arm begins to shake with rage. With a roar, the lifetime cynic declares he'll \"tear it all down.\" If the system is broken, anarchy is the only option.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Sword Art Online: Kirito &#38; Vassago FINALLY Face Off in War of Underworld\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/sword-art-online-alicization-war-underworld-episode-18/\">Sword Art Online: Kirito &#38; Vassago FINALLY Face Off In War Of Underworld</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-natsume-kaburagi-sunset.jpg\"/></figure><p>Kaburagi returns to the correctional facility with the goal of destroying the Gadoll factory, which is apparently right above them. Donatello is on board, but it can't be easy. Their fellow inmates laugh at Kaburagi's face, dismissing him from the get-go. For once, Kaburagi doesn't care about <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/former-sao-ally-rescues-heroes-war-of-underworld-episode-17/\">how hopeless it all looks</a> -- he's contracted Natsume's never-say-die attitude, and this means he'll stop at nothing to save the Tankers.</p><p>It feels as if Kaburagi's new game is a fresh start for him in more ways than one. Not only has he shed his old in-game appearance, but also the attitude that previously defined his character. Filled with resolve, it will be interesting to see how he goes about the seemingly impossible task of destroying the system itself.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/rezero-season-2-episode-7-subaru-witch-cult-garfiel/\">Re:Zero: Subaru REEKS of the Witch Cult and Garfiel Isn't Having It</a></span></p>\n                        \n +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-kaburagi-episode-7.jpg","linkMd5":"2f4b64def981110628374c1d4b3726f6","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn23@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-11-871_da359df8b417ce82.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":59562,"destBytes":59562,"author":"Maxwell Freedman","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-kaburagi-episode-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn23@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-11-871_da359df8b417ce82.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-kaburagi-new-avatar.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-22-581_11dad222b42cc0d5.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/deca-dence-natsume-kaburagi-sunset.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-26-595_667034ddf9b94922.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389183},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Thor Proves That Thanos Is STILL the Marvel Universe's Endgame","link":"https://www.cbr.com/thor-thanos-marvel-endgame/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Thanos-Thor-feature.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </strong></em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/thor\"><strong>Thor</strong></a><em><strong> #6, by Donny Cates, Nic Klein, Matt Wilson and VC's Joe Sabino, on sale now.</strong></em></p><p>Thanos has always been one of the Marvel Universe's most deadly and destructive threats, and entire teams of heroes regularly have used all their might to prevent his plans. But no matter what happens to Thanos, he just keeps coming back to destroy everything.</p><p>In <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-thanos-mjolnir-infinity-upgrades/\">the Black Winter's vision from <em>Thor</em> #6,</a> Thanos is revealed to be responsible for the eventual defeat of Thor- cementing <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-vision-thanos-infinity-mjolnir/\">Thanos</a> as the apparent and inevitable end for Marvel's heroes.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mister-rogers-worthy-mjolnir-donny-cates-thor-fan-comic-marvel-canon/\">Is Mister Rogers Worthy Of Welding Mjolnir? Donny Cates Declares Thor Fan Comic Marvel Canon</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Thor-6-Thanos-Gauntlets.jpg\"/></figure><p>Of all the Marvel villains, Thanos always seemed the most likely to be capable of destroying the heroes once and for all. This has been proven time and time again in the history of the Marvel Universe, with multiple potential futures that have resulted in Thanos wiping out the heroes who've so often stopped him. Jim Starlin, Ron Lim and George Perez's <em>Infinity Gauntlet</em> saw Thanos claim the reality-altering tool and quickly wiping out all opposition, including the last heroes who confronted him. It was only the Gauntlet ending up in the hands of others that all this damage to the universe -- and its heroes -- was undone.</p><p>The impetus of <em>Civil War II</em> -- which saw the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thanos-vision-murder-infinity-gauntlet/\">Avengers</a> using a prediction from the Inhuman Ulysses to ambush Thanos mid-scheme -- kept Thanos from carrying out a plan that would have led to him wiping out half of the Marvel heroes. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thanos-wins-future-king-thanos-intro/\">\"Thanos Wins\"</a> explored a possible future where Thanos did succeed and brutally defeated the heroes during a massive attack on the Earth, eventually becoming the last living being in existence. Even when Thanos had his life altered by a future-Frank Castle, he still killed countless people to achieve a peace he desired for the future, likely including whatever heroes stood in his way.</p><p>These dark ambitions have also stretched beyond comic book universes, with Thanos quickly becoming the overarching villain of the first decade of the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Although he had reasons for his mission, Thanos still set about bringing the destruction of half of all life in the universe to try and achieve a peaceful future. His ambitions led him to claim the Infinity Stones and to wipe out half of all life -- with the heroes being forced to break the laws of space and time to reclaim them and undo the damage he'd caused.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-9-reintroduces-god-of-thunder-human-host-donald-blake/\">Thor #9 Reintroduces The God Of Thunder's Human Host</a></span></p><p>The sheer power of Thanos is only matched by his will, which usually gives him more than enough strength to fight against the heroes of the Marvel Universe. And even though he's dead in the present Marvel Universe, it seems that Thanos is fated to win in the end. After destroying the Black Winter in <em>Thor</em> #6, the Thunder God is forced to witness his final fate at the hands of his otherworldly being. This creates a vision of a broken and defeated world. Bones are strewn across the Earth, and the heroes of the Marvel Universe have been turned into undead ghouls. They follow the command of Thanos - now wielding a mysterious black gauntlet, a stolen Mjolnir, all six of the Infinity Stones and a terrifying grin.</p><p>Even with the Power Cosmic amplifying Thor beyond reason, Thanos is still predicted to be the end of him - and by extension, the last good powers in the Marvel Universe. It seems that no matter what, Thanos is the endgame for the Marvel heroes. No matter what, his future comes into conflict with the heroes - and sets about the end of the heroic age at least, or the universe at worst. Thanos is the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/avengers-infinity-war-concept-artist-thanos-bat-creatures/\">true \"endgame\"</a> for the Marvel Universe.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/what-nick-fury-whispered-thor-unworthy/\">Thor: Three Words Hold More Power Over Marvel's Thunder God Than Anything Else</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 09:20:02 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Thanos-Thor-feature.jpg","linkMd5":"873894547e20f4495163cdee615f0f12","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-09-421_a1e3268dcbfb3c6c.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":160376,"destBytes":160376,"author":"Brandon Zachary","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Thanos-Thor-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-09-421_a1e3268dcbfb3c6c.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Thor-6-Thanos-Gauntlets.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn95@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-22-609_eaea1f517bfc7fe2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389185},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Fullmetal Alchemist: 5 Times Edward Was Right (& 5 Times He Was Horribly Wrong)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-edward-right-wrong/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/edward-right-and-wrong-feature.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>Fullmetal Alchemist </em>began as the story of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-edward-elric-ways-changed-stayed-same/\">Edward</a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-facts-alphonse-elric/\">Alphonse</a> Elric going on a journey to mend their broken bodies and atone for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-edward-alphonses-greatest-sin-explained/\">their sin of human transmutation</a>, but they soon got swept up in a battle for the fate of the entire nation. Father the homunculus wants to become a god, and Ed and Al must face him and his homunculus goons.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemists-best-fights/\">Fullmetal Alchemists: 10 Best Fights in the Series, Ranked</a></span></p><p>Edward is a scientist &#38; an alchemist, like his brother, and he is a skilled, creative martial artist on top of that. Often, the heroes of <em>Fullmetal Alchemist </em>can only advance because of Ed's insights and ideas, though there are also times when he made a mistake or operated under the wrong impression. Here are five times he was right, and five times he made the wrong call or had the wrong idea.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Was Right: Laboratory 5's Significance</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/edward-vs-armor.jpg' /></figure><p>Edward and Al were following a trail of breadcrumbs to find the truth about the Philosopher's Stone, and early in the series, the brothers realized that the abandoned Laboratory #5 was much more important than it looked.</p><p>Ed slipped from the guards and brought Al along. Ed climbed into the ventilation shaft to infiltrate the place while Al waited outside. They got little for it, but Ed was, strictly speaking, correct about Laboratory #5 being a critical part of Father's plans and the production of Philosopher's Stones. He also got the chance to meet Envy and Lust, and learn their faces.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Was Wrong: Performing Human Alchemy</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/human-transmutation.jpg' /></figure><p>Alphonse shares the blame equally with Edward for this. As kids, they suffered the loss of their mother Trisha, then decided to create a formula for bringing her back from the dead. They made a pile of raw ingredients for making a human body, then attempted to transmute Trisha's soul.</p><p>Big mistake. The dead cannot come back to life, and what could have equal value as a human soul? There is no way to make this equivalent exchange, and thus human transmutation is forbidden. Both boys lost parts of their bodies, and Ed has blamed himself in particular for all this ever since then.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Was Right: Cracking Tim Marcoh's Code</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Tim-Marcoh.jpg' /></figure><p>Dr. Tim Marcoh is the man who developed the Philosopher's Stones for the Amestris military's use, and he has been ridden with guilt ever since. But he did leave behind a huge volume of notes, all of them coded so they resembled cookbooks and the like.</p><p>Sheska recreated all the burnt notes from memory, and Ed instantly realized that they were in code. He and Al struggled for days to decipher it all, but they got a second wind, and Ed helped his brother recreate the original version of Dr. Marcoh's notes at last. It was a brilliant move, but all the same, the Erics were horrified by what they had uncoded.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Was Wrong: Holding Back Against Kimblee</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/kimblee-with-red-eyes.jpg' /></figure><p>Later in the story, Ed faced <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-solf-j-kimblee-facts/\">Kimblee</a> in combat in a northern mining town, and Ed was confident about his odds of winning. After all, he had been equipped with lightweight automail that worked well in the cold and he sliced up the transmutation circles on Kimblee's palms.</p><p>The problem is that Kimblee had a Philosopher's Stone on him, and Ed had no way to stop Kimblee from using it &#38; launching a devastating attack. If Ed had killed Kimblee or taken his Stone, then the battle would have turned out differently.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Was Right: About Winry And Killing</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/ed-with-winry.jpg' /></figure><p>Winry came face to face with <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-vital-facts-didnt-know-about-scar/\">Scar</a>, her parents' killer. Winry was consumed with shock, rage, and grief all at once, and she acted rashly by drawing a pistol on Scar. She was sure that shooting Scar would make everything right.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-anime-live-action-comparison-better-worse/\">Fullmetal Alchemist: 5 Things The Live-Action Movie Got Right (&#38; 5 Things The Anime Did Better)</a></span></p><p>Winry was mistaken, however, and she couldn't bring herself to shoot Scar. She fell to her knees, and Ed comforted her, correctly reminding her that her hands are made for healing and fixing, not harming others. If Winry went down the path of revenge and bloodshed, she'd have been lost.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Was Wrong: Trying To Give his Life To Scar</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/edward-vs-scar.jpg' /></figure><p>Early in the series, Scar confronted Ed &#38; Al and targeted them. He was on a mission to assassinate all state alchemists, and he had barely killed Shou Tucker before deciding to move on to the Elrics. He fought them and drove them into a corner.</p><p>Edward faced defeat, and he asked Scar to kill him &#38; spare Al in return. Scar agreed to those terms, but then Roy and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-riza-hawkeye-facts-secrets-trivia/\">Riza Hawkeye</a> intervened. Al was furious that Ed was ready to hand his life over to Scar, since many people are counting on Ed. Besides, Ed was never even a part of the Ishval Civil War.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Was Right: Gluttony's Portal</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/gluttony-stomach-portal.jpg' /></figure><p>Gluttony isn't just hungry. He also has a failed Portal of Truth in his chest, and when it opens, he can absorb anything before him and teleport it to an alternate, infinite dimension. Ed, Envy, and Ling all found themselves trapped in there, seemingly with no way out.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-anime-characters-stronger-wrath/\">Fullmetal Alchemist: 10 Anime Characters Who Are Actually Stronger Than Wrath</a></span></p><p>Edward happened across some ruins from the fallen Xerxes, and recognized the symbols on the stone surface. He then used a piece of Envy's Philosopher's Stone to attempt human transmutation, thus opening the Portal and ejecting the three of them from Gluttony's stomach.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Was Wrong: Blaming Himself For Nina's Fate</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/Full-Metal-Alchemist-Brotherhood-Nina-Tucker-4.jpg' /></figure><p>In one of the most infamous, skin-crawling moments in modern anime, the state alchemist Shou Tucker fused his daughter Nina with his dog Alexander in order to create a chimera and maintain his state alchemy license. Ed and Al had visited the Tucker household a few times in the days leading up to the incident.</p><p>Edward saw Nina's new state and rightfully beat up Shou Tucker, but he kept blaming himself for not taking action sooner. He carried around the weight of Nina's fate, even though it wasn't his fault. He and Al couldn't have known what kind of twisted science Shou Tucker was plotting.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Was Right: Believing In Roy's Ambitions</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Roy-Mustang-2.jpg' /></figure><p>There is a scene where Ed owes <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-roy-mustang-trivia-facts/\">Roy</a> 520 cenz (Amestris currency) for taxi fare or some other minor expense, and Roy demanded the pocket change back. Ed was about to return it, but then he held back and decided to make it more symbolic.</p><p>Ed promised that he would return those 520 cenz when Roy became the new president of Amestris and changed it for the better, and Roy agreed. This shows Ed's deep (and well-placed) faith in Roy Mustang, and it's something that Roy's other friends would have done, too.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Was Wrong: Why He Burned His House Down</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Edward-elric-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>When Edward and Alphonse were ready to start traveling the world, they decided to burn down their family's old house to prove their resolve. They would have nothing to return to, so they'd have no choice but to move forward. Or so they thought.</p><p>When Hohenheim returned to Resembool and met Ed again, he pointed out the <em>real </em>reason Ed burned the house down. Ed and Al were deeply ashamed and frightened of what they had done (human transmutation), and were trying to sweep it under the rug. Ed didn't like being corrected like that, but there was no denying Hohenheim's words.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fullmetal-alchemist-greed-the-rogue-homunculus-explained/\">Fullmetal Alchemist: Greed, the Rogue Homunculus, Explained</a></span></p>\n                        \n
