images.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Edward-elric-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn27@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-26-099_074fcafd9fd0d23b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389170},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"The Flash: Sue Dearbon Will Remain in Season 7 Without Ralph","link":"https://www.cbr.com/the-flash-sue-dearbon-season-7/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/The-Flash-Season-6-Sue-Dearbon.jpg\"/></figure><p>One of the biggest questions surrounding Hartley Sawyer's firing from <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-flash-tv/\">The Flash</a> </em>revolved around what the show would do with the character of Sue Dearbon. Showrunner Eric Wallace revealed that even without the Elongated Man, Sue isn't going anywhere.</p><p>Wallace told <a href=\"https://ew.com/tv/the-flash-season-7-elongated-man-sue-dearbon/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">EW</a>, \"You're going to see Sue more than once this year even without the Elongated Man — on her own, making appearances, and helping Team Flash in an unexpected way. And it's just going to be hilarious because she was so much fun.\"</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/flash-deleted-scene-barry-meets-mirror-iris/\">The Flash Deleted Scene Reveals Barry and Mirror Iris' First Encounter</a></span></p><p>According to Wallace, getting rid of the character of Sue Dearbon was never even an option. He said that keeping Sue around was \"one of the easiest decisions I've ever had to make as a showrunner.\" Wallace added, \"I called up Natalie and said, 'Don't worry, you're still going to be part of this season. We'll find a way.' Now, when I told her that, to be honest, I wasn't quite sure [how]. But I am happy to report we found a way.\"</p><p>Losing Ralph ended up being all the inspiration the writing team needed to give Sue a new arc. Wallace said, \"Now we can expand her character and give her more backstory and more growth in ways that we hadn't initially planned. [It's] really exciting to see how she's going to interact more with Team Flash once her name has been cleared — because we are going to clear her name obviously. But then what's the reason for her to come back to Central City? And that's going to be a bit of her story this season.\" He continued, \"You try to take lemons and make lemonade, and suddenly, now Sue's possibilities are wide open. And we have a particular storyline that she's going to help us out with, [specifically] with one of our villains this season that we would have never gotten to had not the circumstances changed. So it is going to be, I think, fun and unexpected for the audience, as much as it was for us to write.\"</p><p>Back in June, Hartley Sawyer was fired from <em>The Flash </em>after a series of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/flash-hartley-sawyer-fired-racist-misogynistic-tweets/\">racist and misogynistic tweets resurfaced</a>. Because of their marriage in the comics, Sue's plots were often tied to Ralph's in the show, creating a sticky situation for the writers after Sawyer was gone.</p><p>Returning to The CW for Season 7 in 2021, <em>The Flash</em> stars Grant Gustin, Candice Patton, Carlos Valdes, Danielle Panabaker, Tom Cavanagh, Jesse L. Martin and Danielle Nicolet.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/flash-season-7-sizzle-reel/\">The Flash Season 7 Sizzle Reel Teases Barry's Need for Speed, Iris' Mirrorverse Trials</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:10:27 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/The-Flash-Season-6-Sue-Dearbon.jpg","linkMd5":"0e41e808870a458331fdb3c0e124b8d8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-11-833_3a6c64956ea7473a.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":114956,"destBytes":114956,"author":"Evangelia Galanis","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/The-Flash-Season-6-Sue-Dearbon.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-11-833_3a6c64956ea7473a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389171},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"DC Comics: 5 Times Lobo Was A Good Hero (& 5 Times He Was An Awful Villain)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-times-lobo-was-heroic-vs-villainous-justice-league-superman-kalibak/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lobo-Header-Cropped.jpg\"/></figure><p>The character of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/lobo\">Lobo </a>is one of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dc-comics/\">DC Comics'</a> gnarliest anti-heroes whose nearly immortal powers rival that of Kal-El aka <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/superman\">Superman</a>. As as a bounty hunter from the planet Czarnia, Lobo will hunt anyone, anytime, anywhere for the right price -- even if it gets him into big trouble.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lobo-marvel-characters-defeat-lose/\">5 Marvel Characters Lobo Would Defeat (&#38; 5 That Would Destroy Him)</a></span></p><p>Since his initial inception, Lobo has committed his fair share of both good and bad deeds, ranging the gamut of good hero and awful villain. What are some of these acts, and just how good or bad are they? Here are five times Lobo was a good hero and five times he was an awful villain.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Hero: Joined The Justice League</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Lobo-and-the-Justice-League-from-Justice-League.jpg' /></figure><p>In the \"Hereafter\" episode of <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-justice-league-anime-fan-art/\">Justice League</a>, </em>Lobo actually joins the Justice League... and then proceeds to promote himself to the position of leader, of course. Despite this, Lobo did indeed become one of the good guys -- even if he tried to make the enterprise all about himself.</p><p>The event occurs when a group of supervillains attack Metropolis, looking to take revenge on Superman. After a raging fight where it seems the man of steel is killed, the villains continue their attack on the city, battling it out with the other members of the Justice League. Enter Lobo, who steps through a wall of fire and quickly dispatches the villains.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Villain: Fought Superman To Win A Bet</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Lobo-vs-Superman.jpg' /></figure><p>During the Draaga arc, Lobo enters a certain space bar where he overhears a pair of aliens talking about the pending battle between Superman and Draaga himself (while taking wagers on who would win). Lobo naturally enters the conversation, citing that he could take out the man of steel without a fuss.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lobo-15-things-you-must-know-about-the-main-man/\">Lobo: 15 Things You Must Know About The Main Man</a></span></p><p>After getting Lobo severely drunk, the aliens coerce the Czarnian into putting his money where his mouth is, resulting in the main man traveling to the Fortress of Solitude in order to take on the last <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/most-inspirational-quotes-from-superman-comics/\">son of Krypton</a> once and for all. Who wins? Let's just say Superman fakes his own death <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/heroes-superman-did-didnt-defeat/\">just to escape</a>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Hero: Defeated Kalibak</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/KALIBAK.jpg' /></figure><p>Speaking of the Justice League, during his appearance in the episode \"Hereafter\", one of the supervillains terrorizing Metropolis is none other than the eldest son of Darkseid himself: Kalibak. But when Lobo enters the scene during the height of the second battle, he makes quick work of the apokolipian.</p><p>Using a pair of parked cars as bludgeoning devices, Lobo claps Kalibak like a pesky mosquito, hurling the brute into a pile of wreckage. Upon defeating the horde of villains, Lobo forces Darkseid's heir to cry uncle in humiliating fashion.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Villain: Drove His Mother Insane</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/lobo-paramilitary-christmas-special-live-action.jpg' /></figure><p>At birth, Lobo was anything but a peaceful child. After biting the fingers off of the nurse who delivered him, Lobo began demonstrating even stranger and more violent tendencies as a youth.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lobo-things-to-know/\">Czarian Section: 20 Things About Lobo Only True DC Fans Know</a></span></p><p>As such, the dark vibes emitting from Lobo's soul began affecting those around him, including his very own mother. As the main man himself puts it, she went insane after just looking at him... Not that he cared in the least.</p><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Lobo-Space-Dolphins.jpg' /></figure><p>If there's a soft spot in Lobo's heart, it's for one thing and one thing only: Space Dolphins. 'Fishies,' as the insane Czarnian calls them, are a species of dolphin-like creatures that inhabit the vacuum of space. They are intelligent and can communicate with other sentient creatures, of which Lobo has been in close contact since childhood.</p><p>Lobo is especially sentimental about space dolphins and will go to great lengths to protect them at any cost. One example of this occurs when Lobo teams up with Black Canary to save the celestial porpoises from Tribb, a villain using the dolphins as bate to capture the main man. The plan, of course, doesn't work out too well for Tribb as Lobo makes the villain pay dearly for his sins against galactic wildlife.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Villain: Committed Genocide Against His Own Race</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Lobo-Banner.jpg' /></figure><p>Yes, Lobo actually erased his entire species from existence once, demonstrating that he holds no allegiance to any person, place, or thing, least of all his home tribe. Born as a member of the Czarnians from the planet Czarnia, Lobo belongs to a race that not only holds regenerative powers but can only be killed by members of its own species.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"http://www.cbr.com/dc-lobo-worst-things-ever-done-ranked/\">Lobo: The 10 Worst Things That DC's Main Man Has Ever Done, Ranked</a></span></p><p>Naturally, this means Lobo needed to eliminate any threat to his existence -- even if it meant murdering off his own kin. After the deed was done, Lobo commented that he committed the act as a science experiment (of which he gave himself an A+).</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Hero: Helped Defeat Lady Styx</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/young-justice-lobo.jpg' /></figure><p>After the events of 2006's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/infinite-crisis/\"><em>Infinite Crisis</em></a>, Lady Styx places a bounty on the heads of heroes Starfire, Animal Man, and Adam Strange -- all of whom have been left stranded in space. There, they come across the insane Czarnian himself, Lobo, who has recently joined Styx's religion and become the leader of her church. But after some coaxing, the heroes conscript the main man into helping them defeat the supervillain.</p><p>Pretending to be making good on the bounty, Lobo brings the heroes before the Lady, springing their trap upon her once inside. With Lobo's help, the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/teen-titans-most-powerful-strongest-starfire-raven/\">heroes </a>defeat Styx and claim the Emerald Eye.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Villain: Devoured A City</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/lobo-eating-a-city.jpg' /></figure><p>In a demonstration that proves Lobo to be one of the most insane <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/lobo-movie-dc-comics-justice-league-rebirth-facts-trivia/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">characters </a>in comicsland, Lobo once devoured an entire city in a feat of unparalleled power. That's correct, an <em>city</em>!</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-titans-lobo-daughter-crush/\">Titans: 10 Things DC Fans Should Know About Lobo’s Daughter, Crush</a></span></p><p>This is no exaggeration as the Czarnian seemingly managed to crush trillions of tons of steel, stone, and life matter into a single, gobstopper-size ball...then eat it.  Down the hatch in a single bite, the destroyer of worlds cometh...</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Hero: Saved A Planet From Brainiac</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Lobo.jpg' /></figure><p>During the events of <em>R.E.B.E.L.S.</em> Lobo finds himself between a rock in a hard place. Since his Space Church is low on funds, the main man joins Vril Drox in an effort to help battle Brainiac on Planet Colu (for a large sum of cash). Using the red ring of the Lantern Corps, Lobo descends onto Colu and enters the action.</p><p>However, despite his best efforts, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-brainiac-cosplay-dc-comics/\">Brainiac </a>manages to escape along with Pulsar Stargrave. Nonetheless, Lobo did indeed save Colu and the people thereupon, making him a hero in his own right.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Villain: Killed Santa Claus</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/lobo-santa-e1527798091640.jpg' /></figure><p>Believe it or not, this actually happned in the comics. Lobo was hired by the Easter Bunny to take out Kris Kringle himself, eliminating Easter's competition and asserting his place atop the hierarchy of holiday mascots.</p><p>So what does Lobo do? Why take the case, of course! Money is, after all, money, and the only color the main man sees is green. After taking the job, Lobo tracks Saint Nick down and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-hanna-barbera-crossover-powerpuff-girls-lobo/\">beats </a>him to death -- using strength enough to destroy even the man of steel.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/five-dc-titles-set-to-end-including-justice-league-united-and-lobo/\">Titans: 10 Things DC Fans Should Know About Lobo’s Daughter, Crush</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 14:30:06 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lobo-Header-Cropped.jpg","linkMd5":"9ab6afd9dd247c3c481709500363c290","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-476_a927311ae62e8e79.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":218416,"destBytes":218416,"author":"Luke Penn","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Lobo-Header-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-476_a927311ae62e8e79.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Lobo-and-the-Justice-League-from-Justice-League.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-22-511_fe0eb6ebc7d4552a.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/Lobo-vs-Superman.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-26-760_72414569cb8986a1.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/KALIBAK.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-28-108_8808df95ae8657a2.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/lobo-paramilitary-christmas-special-live-action.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-23-458_35f84bdfc3519b62.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Lobo-Space-Dolphins.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn3@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-31-753_e5ee70b2f7f8b7b0.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Lobo-Banner.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn64@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-22-329_5d7265650beb2acd.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/01/young-justice-lobo.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-21-187_00c4c46e0d2696ab.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/lobo-eating-a-city.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-25-221_715f3333e043ad44.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/Lobo.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn7@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-30-943_d5ab1e97eeeedc38.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/lobo-santa-e1527798091640.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-24-219_0495422db5fba307.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389183},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Marvel: 10 Awesome Facts About Luke Cage's Body | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-luke-cages-biology-facts/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Marvel-Luke-Cage-1-Cropped.jpg\"/></figure><p dir=\"ltr\">Marvel's very own Power Man, Luke Cage became one of the most sought out superheroes in the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvel-comics/\">Marvel Comics</a> after Netflix released the character's original series, although it was cut short, thanks to disagreements between Marvel Television and Netflix.</p><p dir=\"ltr\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Iron Fist Vs. Luke Cage: Who Would Win In A Fight?\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-iron-fist-vs-luke-cage-win-lose-fight/\">Iron Fist Vs. Luke Cage: Who Would Win In A Fight?</a></span></p><p dir=\"ltr\">Luke Cage's first appearance came in the comic named <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/luke-cage/\">Luke Cage</a>, <em>Hero For Hire #1</em> and the character itself was created by George Tuska, John Romita, Archie Goodwin, and Ray Thomas. With the concentration being around Cage's supposed powers, the comics over the years have revealed so much about the Avenger's unbreakable skin. There are so many things the fans need to know about Cage's body and here are a few awesome facts about the same.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>He Wasn't Born With It</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cbr-luke-cage-moment-of-truth-1.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">While Luke <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-heroes-weird-origin-powers-story/\">would have wanted to be born a superhero, unfortunately, it didn't pan out that way as he has a proper origin story</a>, which is both sad and painful. Born in Harlem, Luke was arrested for doing nothing and he volunteered for a science experiment, which saw a copy of the Super Soldier Serum (the one used on Steve Rogers) being used on him. The experiment took a drastic turn and he developed an unbreakable body, along with the other perks.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>He Is Fast, Really Fast</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Marvel-Luke-Cage-1-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">This <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superhero-comics-silliest-powers-ranked/\">seems to be an underrated power</a> of Luke Cage. The Power Man of Marvel Comics didn't just gain superhuman strength from the serum, his body also became very light and he is someone who can swiftly cover ground. A glimpse of the same can be seen in the Netflix series and in Marvel's The Defenders. Luke literally is able to chase down a truck and he doesn't even break a sweat. It's absolutely incredible the amount of acceleration he can gain for such a big body.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Superhuman Stamina</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Luke-Cage-2.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">With the ability to cover long distances in a short space of time, Luke also has absolutely incredible stamina. It seems like serum adjusted his stamina according to the levels of strength in his body.</p></p><p><p dir=\"ltr\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"10 Things Marvel Fans Don't Know About Jessica Jones &#38; Luke Cage's Relationship\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-comics-jessica-jones-luke-cage-relationship-facts-trivia/\">10 Things Marvel Fans Don't Know About Jessica Jones &#38; Luke Cage's Relationship</a></span></p></p><p><p dir=\"ltr\">He can fight for as long as the opponent wears out or eventually gives up. It's just like Captain America and no wonder why <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-characters-comic-teams-leader/\">Luke seems to have these leadership qualities</a>; he can literally do it all day. In the comics, Luke has stood up for some incredible battles.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Healthy Appetite</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Luke-Cage.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">Despite being super strong, it comes across as a genuine surprise that Luke Cage doesn't have a weird appetite. He eats as much as a normal human being does and so far, he has shown no signs of an extraordinary diet. The reason why it comes across as a surprise is that Luke's body is able to churn out incredible feats of strength, which means the muscles use a lot of energy and hence why he should feel the need to eat food at regular intervals. But it seems like Luke's digestive system works a bit differently</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Superhuman Healing Abilities</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Luke-Cage.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">If the superhuman strength, stamina, and power weren't enough, Luke Cage also has incredible healing abilities but not at the level of a Wolverine or Deadpool. Instead, he is at a level where his body can heal in days when for a normal human being it should take weeks, at least. While Luke doesn't really suffer from fatal injuries day in day out, whenever he does suffer from dangerous injuries, he is able to get back up on his feet pretty quickly.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>The Delivery Is Important</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Luke-Cage.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">Even though Luke Cage has <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-healing-factors-marvel-comics-ranked/#:~:text=There%20are%20a%20few%20abilities,far%20quicker%20than%20other%20characters\">a superb healing factor in his body</a>, that doesn't make him immune to every type of poison present in the universe. Also, it depends heavily on the fact that from where the poison is getting into his body. If it's through his chest, biceps, or even wrist, chances are they will not affect him. It's really very hard to pin down the Power Man but if one is really careful, then he/she can succeed, with the emphasis on the word success.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Energy Blasts Need To Be Good</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Luke-Cage-Mighty-Avengers.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">Luke Cage's unbreakable skin is so good that most kinds of energy blasts don't end up doing anything to him. They just tickle him, quite literally, and even Iron Man has struggled to do anything to him through his renowned energy blasts.</p></p><p><p dir=\"ltr\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"5 Times Mike Colter's Luke Cage Was Comics Accurate (&#38; 5 Times He Wasn't)\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/luke-cage-mike-colter-comics-accuracy/\">5 Times Mike Colter's Luke Cage Was Comics Accurate (&#38; 5 Times He Wasn't)</a></span></p></p><p><p dir=\"ltr\"><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-the-crew-every-team-member/\">In one comic representing The Crew, Luke came up against Hydra and they tried to blast him off using a rocket launcher</a>. And guess what, when the rocket landed, everything in and around the area got destroyed but there was Luke standing tall like nothing even happened.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Lasers Can Affect Him</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Luke-Cage.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">Luke's outer body is like an armor that protects his organs but if someone can find a way to break through the body without actually tearing him apart then something can definitely happen. That's where these small yet powerful lasers come into play because they can cause damage to Cage's internal body structure. Like if a powerful beam of X-Ray is used on him, maybe some of his organs might start failing. But in order to reach that far, one has to trick Cage which is easier said than done.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>His Head Is His Biggest Weakness</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/luke-cage-dab.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\">If there's any part of Luke Cage's body that is vulnerable to a simple blow is his head because a blunt trauma to his head can affect him as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-comics-underrated-overrated-stories-events/\">seen in Marvel's The Defenders story arc</a> when Elektra is able to leave him unconscious by landing a blow to his head. Concussions can have a huge effect on Cage as it does to many other superheroes, even Thanos who pretty much told Thor that he should have gone for the head.</p></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Vulnerable To Wolverine's Claws</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Marvel-Comics-Luke-Cage.jpg' /></figure><p><p dir=\"ltr\"><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-wolverine-common-misconceptions/\">Wolverine's claws are made out of Adamantium</a>, so it can be said that Luke Cage's body can be penetrated by using this fictional metal alloy that is found in the Marvel Universe. Over the years, <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/tag/Wolverine/\">Wolverine</a>'s claws have broken through the likes of Hulk, so it wouldn't surprise anyone if it has the same effects on Cage. It would be really interesting to note that Cage might be open to infections if he suffers a clean blow but that doesn't happen very often.</p></p><p><p dir=\"ltr\"><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"5 Luke Cage Costumes That We Love (&#38; 5 That We Don't)\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/luke-cage-marvel-best-worst-outfits/\">5 Luke Cage Costumes That We Love (&#38; 5 That We Don't)</a></span></p></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:30:30 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Marvel-Luke-Cage-1-Cropped.jpg","linkMd5":"17390ba2d6afef1c0b109d9a8e31fb85","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-11-981_c8e1dbb531eb12ba.webp","destWidth":1820,"destHeight":910,"sourceBytes":163074,"destBytes":163074,"author":"Nishid Motwani","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Marvel-Luke-Cage-1-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-11-981_c8e1dbb531eb12ba.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cbr-luke-cage-moment-of-truth-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn59@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-24-661_abe01e60cf168acd.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Luke-Cage-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn66@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-21-266_385a70001cb733a5.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Luke-Cage.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-24-916_9ceff94c611e2e27.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Luke-Cage.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-31-983_429ed7e010c9616f.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Luke-Cage.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn63@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-26-451_3b9ec39e8939bb57.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Luke-Cage-Mighty-Avengers.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn96@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-26-645_15af0f4096410b64.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Luke-Cage.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-35-667_127939b47a1974b8.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/luke-cage-dab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-25-913_9d11bd4626f779d0.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Marvel-Comics-Luke-Cage.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-23-285_6f9a7d22eff9a907.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389170},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Berserk: 5 Things That Make No Sense About The Show (& 5 Fan Theories That Do)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-anime-manga-no-sense-fan-theories/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Berserk-Fan-Theories-No-Sense.jpg\"/></figure><p>Kentaro Miura's award-winning and well-loved action Seinen manga <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/berserk/\">Berserk</a> </em>has not only made huge impressions on the people who have come in contact with it, but it also kind of stumped them on a lot as well. The manga prominently features a lot of complex themes and lore that, even with a very close reading of it, can be baffling.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-guts-versus-anime-characters-win-lose/\">5 Characters From Anime Guts Could Beat (&#38; 5 He Can't)</a></span></p><p>Aside from that, there are many mysteries that Miura has left unsolved in part thanks to his habitual long hiatuses and noticeably slowed output. Here's a look into some things that don't make sense yet, and some fan theories about <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/kentaro-miuras-8-best-works-that-arent-berserk-ranked/\">Kentaro Miura's magnum opus</a> that may help us to figure them out.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>MAKES NO SENSE: What Exactly Is A Behelit?</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/behelit-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>From what's shown, a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-apostles-little-know-trivia/\">Behelit</a> is perhaps some weird sort of baby head or something, right? Well, not really. But that description is <em>kind of</em> correct, right? In <em>Berserk</em>, the Behelit is a supernatural item that provides otherworldly power to its. That is, if they know how to use it.</p><p>We see Behelits used multiple times, once by Griffith and by a host of other antagonists who become Apostles. It allows one to make a wish, provided the God Hand -- ethereal beings straight out of <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/hellraiser-remake-production-hell/\">Hellraiser</a> --</em> decides it's a worthy cause. We know how they work, but who made them and why? And why do they choose people as if they're conscious?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>FAN THEORY: Destiny doesn't exist</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/destiny.jpg' /></figure><p>While there are heavy themes of will and destiny in the story, we could also assume that in a world as broken as <em>Berserk's</em>, maybe there is no grander scheme of things. While Miura has said in interviews he can't give a series as dark as <em>Berserk</em> a bad ending, that doesn't necessarily mean that it's fated for Guts or Griffith to automatically win or lose.</p><p>Although Griffith has achieved his dream -- a major event that gives fate's existence credence -- Guts' vengeance is nigh, even with the entirety of existence against him. Either Guts' reckoning proves that destiny is false or, at the very least, he's actively defying it.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>MAKES NO SENSE: Is The Demon Child Really Gone?</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/demon-child-berserk-1.jpg' /></figure><p>There's sort of a specter haunting the background of the main characters in <em>Berserk</em>. This specter is misshapen, frail, and ugly. That isn't an insult or anything, but perhaps that gives us a hint at who or what exactly it is.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-guts-worst-things-happened/\">Berserk: 10 Of The Worst Things That Happened To Guts</a></span></p><p>It's revealed that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-guts-versus-anime-characters-win-lose/\">Guts </a>is father to the Demon Child (as named in the manga) that Casca prematurely gave birth to, though it was corrupted by Femto (Griffith's Godhand form) during the Eclipse. The Demon Child later becomes Griffith's new corporeal form, but is this the last fans have seen of it? What else does it have in store for the plot, since its influence can be felt even after its supposed sacrifice?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>FAN THEORY: The Demon Child Will Be Instrumental In Griffith's Downfall</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/griffiths-downfall.jpg' /></figure><p>Skull Knight confirmed that the Demon Child is evil, despite being the offspring of Guts and Casca. The child was intended to be the vessel for Femto to incarnate in the material world after Griffith forced himself upon Casca, but he merely corrupted a child that was already there.</p><p>As mentioned earlier, the Demon Child is (technically) the new Griffith, which is why it makes sense that it would hurt him in the long run -- especially since it can subtly influence him, like how Griffith has a strange urge to protect Casca that he couldn't explain. Perhaps Griffith's downfall will take place when distracted in battle by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-dc-superheroes-vs-guts/\">Guts</a>, and Casca will have her revenge since the child (living in Griffith) is unable to harm her.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>MAKES NO SENSE: Is Skull Knight A Friend Or Foe?</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/skull-knight-1.jpg' /></figure><p>There's something about <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-skull-knight-facts/\">Skull Knight</a> that we can't quite put our finger on. Not only does he look fairly demonic but Guts has had more than a couple of hostile run-ins with him, even though Skull Knight has generally been disarming and portrayed himself as an ally. But is he really a friend?</p><p>Skull Knight did help Guts get the Berserker armor and everything, after showing him where to go and providing him a sense of direction. That being said, he's not a normal human and he seems to have beef with Zodd. While Zodd is most likely all enemy, is Skull Knight manipulating Guts and using him for his own plans, or are his feelings sincere?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>FAN THEORY: Skull Knight Is Supreme King Gaiseric</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Gaiseric.jpg' /></figure><p>Gaiseric was the emperor of the first empire that existed in what is now Falconia, and in the middle of these two was Midland. According to the Holy See, Gaiseric imprisoned a sage in a tower and from there, what Griffith did to Guts happens. Gaiseric is visited by four or five angels, the sage sacrifices Gaiseric's entire kingdom, and the sage (supposedly) becomes Void of the God Hand.</p><p>This fan theory states that Gaiseric and Skull Knight being the same person, as Gaiseric wore a skull helmet and was known as the Skull King. We also see Skull Knight attacking Void specifically during the Eclipse, since he has a \"mysterious\" hatred for this specific God Hand member. This one may be bit of a deep lore dive and while it hasn't been spelled out just yet, we're willing to go ahead and accept it as fact.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>MAKES NO SENSE: What's Zodd's Deal?</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/zodd-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Zodd, also known as Zodd The Immortal or Nosferatu Zodd, is a rather interesting presence in <em>Berserk</em>. He's been a continuous thorn in Guts' side since early on in the series. People have a few strange ideas about him, mostly in regards to the fact that he does look mysteriously similar to Guts.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-apostles-little-know-trivia/\">Berserk: 10 Things You Didn't Know About Apostles</a></span></p><p>Is that, again, an example of foreshadowing for things to come? Zodd serves Griffith for now but if Guts and Griffith's broken bridge is anything to go by, Zodd's servitude may be temporary. Maybe Zodd is a twisted mirror of Guts' worst side?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>FAN THEORY: Guts Will Destroy Himself</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/guts-destroy-himself.jpg' /></figure><p>One of the biggest worries in the series is that the Berserker Armor isn't a stable option for Guts. Not only is it not the best at healing people because it merely resets bones and fills cuts up instead of properly fixing the problem, but it also brings Guts closer to losing himself to the dark beast that lurks in him, waiting to consume him and take control.</p><p>This beast may, at the end of the day, be the only thing that can defeat Griffith, but it would also mean <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-guts-worst-things-happened/\">Guts</a> losing himself completely if that's what ends up happening at the end of their eventual clash.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>MAKES NO SENSE: How Does Time Work?</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/time.jpg' /></figure><p>One of the strangest things about the world/s of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/vinland-saga-ways-anime-better-berserk-best/\"><em>Berserk</em> </a>is that while it's already strange that there are three realms (the Astral, Physical and Ideal Worlds) that only begin to overlap once the Eclipse happens, there also isn't a set time period over which the series takes place.</p><p>There are periods where there are time skips but there are also periods where Guts experiences something like \"lost time.\" He spends nights, weeks, months, years wandering and surviving onslaughts of demons, barely aging at all. Additionally, was <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/berserk-anime-characters-that-could-defeat-griffith/\">Griffith </a>added to the God Hand or has he always been a part of their plan that transcends time? Was he already Femto before the Eclipse, merely given flesh?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>FAN THEORY: The God Hand Is Using Griffith</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/godhand.jpg' /></figure><p>Void is probably the most important part of the God Hand. This is seen in how Void manipulates events to his accord, with him getting Griffith to emulate Gaiseric both in empire and power for reasons unknown. It would make a lot of sense to assume that with all of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/h-p-lovecraft-and-the-horror-of-comics/\">Lovecraftian</a> themes in the manga, that the God Hand has a certain agenda in mind and is merely using Griffith to achieve it.</p><p>It seems that there is a<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-vs-dark-souls-3-better-game/\"> </a><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-3-vs-dark-souls-3-better-game/\">Dark Souls</a>-</em>like cycle at work here. Maybe Griffith is merely a pawn, despite the illusion of true power he found when he became Femto. The God Hand's ultimate goal has yet to be revealed.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/manga-read-liked-berserk/\">10 Manga To Read If You Liked Berserk</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 14:30:09 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Berserk-Fan-Theories-No-Sense.jpg","linkMd5":"65bb62f971480750192103011cfcb116","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn23@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-450_dcaba998f53d9e40.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":203712,"destBytes":203712,"author":"Cody McIntosh","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Berserk-Fan-Theories-No-Sense.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn23@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-450_dcaba998f53d9e40.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/behelit-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn58@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-27-076_c2064e7f5569b750.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/destiny.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-30-506_8b171f83f19a4b84.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/demon-child-berserk-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn7@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-24-511_104598d8e4777e4c.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/griffiths-downfall.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-31-510_6a34904e1cf9754f.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/skull-knight-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn67@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-23-907_e18350e9df7ad83f.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Gaiseric.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn59@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-28-048_34a230367d509818.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/zodd-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn100@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-21-133_9f059bd5a782337c.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/guts-destroy-himself.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn7@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-26-887_97daaf439edbf574.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/time.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-30-491_e7c3ae6d57c0608d.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/godhand.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-21-464_bd132e66151ac5f0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389183},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Marvel's Avengers Assemble in Launch Trailer | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-launch-trailer-drops/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvels-Avengers-A-Day-team.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvels-avengers/\">Marvel's Avengers</a> </em>is one of the most anticipated games of the year --and it's slated to launch next week. Now, a brand new trailer for the game has dropped.</p><p>The trailer for the upcoming game can be seen below.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-storage-space-ps4/\">Marvel's Avengers Takes Up a MASSIVE Amount of the Playstation 4's Storage Space</a></span></p><iframe width=\"480\" height=\"270\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/x91lpMZ_wWk?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen></iframe><p>The game will open by telling the story of a mission that ended in tragedy for the Avengers. After Captain America's death, the team disbands in their grief. Eventually, Kamala Khan takes it upon herself to reunite Earth's Mightiest Heroes. After being exposed to the Terrigen mists, Kamala transforms into the superhero Ms. Marvel, but she isn't the only one who will have ties to the Terrigen mists. A.I.M. (Advanced Idea Mechanics) intends to harness and use the mists for their own, unsavory purposes. A.I.M. also \"steps up\" in the Avengers' absence, utilizing their technology to help humankind.</p><p>The Avengers line up in the game includes Iron Man, Thor, Hulk and Black Widow --with several other characters rumored as later additions.</p><p>Developed by Crystal Dynamics and Eidos-Montréal and published by Square Enix, <em>Marvel's Avengers</em> arrives on PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Google Stadia and PC on Sept. 4.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-first-look-modok-monica-rappaccini/\">Marvel's Avengers Debuts First Look at MODOK, Monica Rappaccini</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:28:15 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvels-Avengers-A-Day-team.jpg","linkMd5":"f7dc037bbab6e9a39015d6ae3e26545e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-11-176_79b72bd24463651f.webp","destWidth":1600,"destHeight":800,"sourceBytes":90808,"destBytes":90808,"author":"Evangelia Galanis","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvels-Avengers-A-Day-team.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-11-176_79b72bd24463651f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389171},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Paranoia Agent: 10 Things That Make No Sense About Lil' Slugger","link":"https://www.cbr.com/paranoia-agent-10-things-that-make-no-sense-about-lil-slugger/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lil-slugger-confessino.jpg\"/></figure><p>For a show that diminishes the line between right and wrong, <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/paranoia-agent/\">Paranoia Agent</a></em> elaborated a little less than usual on the show’s antagonist, “Lil' Slugger.” From the first episode, Li'l Slugger is portrayed as the fifth-grader who assaults people in the dark alleys of Tokyo. He is grim, merciless, juvenile, and carries a bent-baseball bat to knock out people who are emotionally <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/paranoia-agent-creepiest-moments-ranked/\">cornered by their fears</a>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/anime-underrated-psychological-anime-crunchyroll/\">10 Underrated Psychological Anime You Can Watch On Crunchyroll</a></span></p><p>Among various masterpieces like <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/perfect-blue-things-never-knew-anime-movie-trivia-haunting/\">Perfect Blue</a></em> and<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/millennium-actress-anime-film-ahead-of-its-time/\"> <em>Millennium Actress</em></a>, the late <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/satoshi-kon-movies-ranked-imdb/\">Satoshi Kon’s</a> <em>Paranoia Agent</em> is a satire of everyday human life. The show has some amazing imagery and symbolism but is often hard for viewers to understand. The symbolism is subtle throughout the series, especially in the fifth episode when both Keiichi Ikari and Mitsuhiro Maniwa visit Tsukiko in the hospital. There are more scenes and theories that are either too subtle or don't make any sense regarding Lil' Slugger and Tsukiko.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Is Lil' Slugger Really A Hallucination?</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lil-slugger-enters.jpg' /></figure><p>A few episodes into the series and the most obvious clue in the Lil' Slugger case was Tsukiko Sagi. As the first assault victim, Tsukiko was depicted as a delusional person who created a paracosm surrounding her childhood pet dog, Maromi. Both police and media bought into this story of lies and delusions without looking into her mental state.</p><p>If Lil' Slugger was only a character from Tsukiko's childhood trauma, then how were people assaulted by her idea of fear and paranoia?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Makoto Kozuka</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lil-Slugger-arrested.jpg' /></figure><p>When Makoto was arrested by the police, the victims quickly recognized him as the notorious Lil' Slugger. But in the earlier part of the investigation, all of the victims confirmed they never saw their attacker's face. But the police officers never cross-checked the old statements with the new ones.</p><p>How do Makoto and Lil' Slugger share the exact face, height, and skills? Who was copying who? How did Lil' Slugger copy Makoto, when Makoto confessed he was playing the role of a fake Lil' Slugger? Too many questions were left unanswered. Maybe reading the manga would help!</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Makoto's Victims</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Makoto-Paranoia-agent-.jpg' /></figure><p>In episode 5, the imposter Lil' Slugger finally debuts, and his side of the story differs entirely from what viewers have seen in the Lil' Slugger case. Makoto Kozuka is a second-year student from Minami Junior High School who struggles with Chuunibyou syndrome. This rare condition is mostly used to describe the fictional world created by children and teens.</p><p>Makoto is the delusional knight who liberates people by hitting them with his holy sword (er, baseball bat). But how does Makoto find his victims? Both Ushiyama and Hirukawa were emotionally exhausted and Makoto attacked them in the middle of their crisis. If Makoto was able to sense the emotional state of his victims then maybe he was indeed the original Lil' Slugger all along.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>The Death Of Makoto Kozuka</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Giant-Lil-Slugger.jpg' /></figure><p>Satoshi Kon flawlessly convinced viewers into believing in Lil' Slugger's existence. And no information was provided around the fake Shonen batboy, Makoto Kozuka. In episode 5, Makoto was struggling with a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/honest-portrayals-mental-illness-graphic-memoirs/\">mental disorder</a> and in his confession, Makoto called himself \"The Holy Warrior\" who protects people from the evil Gohma.</p><p>In episode 7, after interrogating Makoto for the previous assaults, Maniwa goes out to meet other possible suspects. In the meantime, Makoto dies in the lockup room. It's unclear if Lil' Slugger actually killed him or not. There was nothing in the lockup room that could hurt Makoto, so how did he die?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Origin Of The Shonen Bat</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Tsukiko-and-lil-slugger.jpg' /></figure><p>One thing that didn't make any sense is the origin of Lil' Slugger. If Lil' Slugger was created by Tsukiko's past trauma then it shouldn't have assaulted other individuals. It is not clear if suffering from office stress is the same as suffering from a disassociative identity disorder in this story. If Harumi Chōno, Akio Kawazu, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/paranoia-agent-anime-cosplay-identical-characters/\">and other characters</a> were facing different fears then the manifestation of their fears should be different too.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-80s-horror-anime/\">10 Best '80s Horror Anime (According to My Anime List)</a></span></p><p>Lil' Slugger is theoretically the manifestation of Tsukiko’s childhood trauma, not everyone else’s. A fine example of this kind of shapeshifting fear is visible in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/scariest-stephen-king-novels-ranked/\">Stephen King's</a> <em>IT</em>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>How Lil' Slugger Chooses Its Victims</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Identity-disorder-in-paranoia-agent.jpg' /></figure><p>Every human faces some sort of fear. But in <em>Paranoia Agent</em>, each of the victims have different fears and insecurities, but their manifestation of fear was the same. Tsukiko was afraid of the next character design and Harumi Chono had a severe mental illness. Akio Kawazu was stressed out due to financial debt and Kamome, Fuyubachi, and Zebra wanted to commit group suicide.</p><p>Lil' Slugger failed to assault some of the most emotionally trapped individuals like Kamome, Fuyubachi, Zebra, Misae Ikari, and the mysterious old man. If it can assault emotionally stressed people then how did it fail to attack these individuals? It's still unclear where Lil' Slugger draws the line.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>The Detective's Instincts Fail</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Makoto-fictional-world.jpg' /></figure><p>In episode 7, Mitsuhiro Maniwa finally discovers the Lil' Slugger assault patterns. He then confirms his theory with Keiichi Ikari but Ikari removes himself from the Lil' Slugger case. But he was the first person who proposed the theory that Tsukiko was lying. It doesn't make any sense if Ikari tries to quit when all they have to do is question Tsukiko again.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/four-essential-satoshi-kon-films-paranoia-agent/\">Four Essential Satoshi Kon Films to Watch After Paranoia Agent</a></span></p><p>Ikari was never diagnosed with any medical condition in the show, nor he was terrified of Lil Slugger's existence. He was one of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/paranoia-agent-smartest-characters-ranked/\">smartest characters</a> in the series, but why did he back off when they were so close to the truth?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>The Unknown Character</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Old-man-from-paranoia-agent.jpg' /></figure><p>In the first episode, an old man writes some formulas in a parking lot in an apparently unconnected scene. Apart from being a catalyst in Mitsuhiro Maniwa's imaginative adventures, the old man didn't have any relevance to Lil' Slugger in this <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/underated-psychological-anime-funimation/\">psychological anime</a>. He was undoubtedly the most unnecessary character in <em>Paranoia Agent</em>.</p><p>He is not the Shonen Bat, nor he is a medieval master as cited by Maniwa. The relationship between the old man and Lil' Slugger is not clear. Interestingly, the old man was always shown as cornered and helpless but Lil' Slugger never attacked him.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Giant Lil' Slugger</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lil-slugger-doenst-make-any-sense.jpg' /></figure><p>In episode 12, Lil' Slugger transforms into a giant monster. His face changes from a kid's into a fanged demon's. But how did he grow so big?</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/paranoia-agent-anime-cosplay-identical-characters/\">10 Awesome Paranoia Agent Cosplays That Look Exactly Like The Characters</a></span></p><p><span class=\"related-single\">None of the victims, including Tsukiko, changed substantially since the first episode. So why there was a 15 foot Lil' Slugger instead of the regular one? This increase in size and monstrosity didn’t make any sense. If Lil' Slugger indeed feeds upon fear then why didn't it transform after the first assault? </span></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Fake Black Ooze</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Black-ooze-in-paranoia-agent.jpg' /></figure><p>In the series' last episode, black ooze eats everything, but why does it also affect the people who have nothing to do with the case? In this episode, Lil' Slugger takes this bizarre ooze-form and submerges the city in darkness.</p><p>If Lil' Slugger is only a creation of Tsukiko's mind then how did this hallucination destroy an entire, physical, city in the real world?</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/paranoia-agent-similar-anime/\">10 Mystery Anime To Watch If You Like Paranoia Agent</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:30:49 b2b4b1df6.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Black-ooze-in-paranoia-agent.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn48@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-28-595_02c1ad97a608d73c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389169},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"My Hero Academia: 5 Characters Fans Want Shoto To End Up With (& 5 That Are More Likely)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-shoto-todoroki-characters-fans-relationships/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/My-Hero-Academia-5-Characters-Fans-Want-Shoto-To-End-Up-With-5-That-Are-More-Likely-featured-image.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/my-hero-academia/\">My Hero Academia</a></em> has proven its meddle as one of the most important <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shonen-anime-2010-overlooked-way-popular/\">shonen of the 2010s</a>, but what about the ships though? In the same way that the show had a chip on its shoulder and something to prove, so does the subject of this article, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-didnt-know-about-shoto-todoroki/\">Shoto Todoroki</a>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-manga-couples-teased-fans-want/\">My Hero Academia: 5 Pairings The Manga Has Already Teased (&#38; 5 Fans Want To See Happen)</a></span></p><p>He's a rather impressive hero, hampered by the actions and personality of his father, who he almost completely rejects. Because of this, Todoroki has had a whole lot to overcome to be able to embody every part of himself. The one frontier he hasn't challenged yet... is love!</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Likely Pick: Momo Yaoyorozu</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/momo-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>Momo Yaoyorozu, known by the hero name Everything Hero: Creati, is a pretty capable person. Her Quirk allows her to create any sort of inanimate object out of her fat cells, making her well-rounded for support, defense, or offense. She's also one of the only women that Shoto Todoroki has interacted with in the show.</p><p>There's tons of speculation about their budding feelings for each other based on the fact that Momo spent tons of time looking up to Shoto, to the point where she was insecure about her abilities.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Fan Pick: Ibara Shiozaki</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/ibara.jpg' /></figure><p>Perhaps the biggest reason that Ibara and Shoto would be a good match is the fact that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-10-strongest-women-in-my-hero-academia-ranked-according-to-strength/\">both of them have powerful quirks</a>, but they have certain reasons for not using them offensively.</p><p>While they haven't interacted much in the show (and both fire and ice present some serious danger to plants), this combination of similarities and opposite traits would make them a great couple.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Likely Pick: Eijiro Kirishima</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/eijiro.jpg' /></figure><p>In a specific instance, it's shown that while <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-facts-didnt-know-eijiro-kirishima/\">Eijiro </a>and Shoto didn't start as the best of friends, they were generally near each other and seemed aware of the serious skills the other possessed.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-5-reasons-why-explosion-is-better-than-one-for-all-5-one-for-all-reigns-supreme/\">My Hero Academia: 5 Reasons Why Explosion Is Better Than One For All (&#38; 5 One For All Reigns Supreme)</a></span></p><p>Aside from that, they start to form a relationship after competing in events together. At one point when Shoto gets discouraged, Eijiro is right there at his side to console and help him feel more confident about his performance.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Fan Pick: Inasa Yoarashi</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/inasa.jpg' /></figure><p>Inasa is a pretty weird character. He has an absolute grudge against Shoto's father, a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mha-student-costumes-pro-ready-could-use-work/\">Pro Hero</a> known as Endeavor. While this is a trait that two of them share, when Inasa first meets Shoto, the former is instantly met with the icy (no pun intended) demeanor that the latter is well-known around the school for.</p><p>Luckily, while Inasa quickly developed the same dislike for Shoto that he has against Endeavor, after a while, he was able to apologize. Maybe if they continue this coming together and squashing of beef, they'll head towards a meaningful relationship.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Likely Pick: Kyoka Jiro</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kyoka-jiro-1.jpg' /></figure><p>It's really hard to tell if this one is more of a fan pick or just a pretty likely pairing. Shoto and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-kyoka-jiro-facts-trivia/\">Kyoka</a> are two of the most popular characters among fans, but that doesn't necessarily mean that they need to have anything to do with one another.</p><p>That being said, if one digs into them a little more as characters, they're both people who wear a mask of being cold and detached from those who are closest to them. Once past their exteriors, they are considerate.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Fan Pick: Tenya Iida</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/iida-1.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-tenya-iida-facts/\">Tenya Iida</a> and Shoto share a pretty big similarity. They both have a lot to live up to in regards to being related to some pretty popular and respected heroes.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-one-for-all-hidden-powers/\">My Hero Academia: 10 Powers You Didn't Know One For All Offered</a></span></p><p>Even though this is probably more of a fan pick than a likely path for the show to take, it would theoretically make sense since they are good friends. The only issue is that Shoto hates his father, but Iida loves his brother. It's a bit of a big difference in personality.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Likely Pick: Katsuki Bakugo</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bakugo-Cropped-1.jpg' /></figure><p>This one might be another hybrid of both a fan pick and a likely pick, but that's just because <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-facts-never-knew-bakugo/\">Bakugo</a> is a pretty popular ship member no matter who he's paired with.</p><p>In the same way that everyone loved Sasuke in <em>Naruto</em> even if he didn't necessarily deserve it, people feel the same way about the hotheaded Bakugo. Maybe if Shoto can go ahead and indulge in his fire side, they could make things work one day.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Fan Pick: Himiko Toga</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/toga.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-mha-facts-interesting-trivia-history-himiko-toga/\">Himiko Toga</a> is a pretty evil character. There's no way around that, even though she's also a fan favorite. There's also something that, while it's not likely to actually happen in the universe of the show, could make for a pretty reasonable assumption about their possible romance. Toga and Shoto's older brother are in the League of Villains together.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-pokemon-ochaco-uraraka-can-cant-defeat/\">My Hero Academia: 5 Pokémon Ochaco Uraraka Could Defeat (&#38; 5 She Would Lose To)</a></span></p><p>It would take a lot to get them lined up to date one day, perhaps even a complete personality change from both. Maybe Shoto's familiarity would be a way for Toga to end up with feelings.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Likely Pick: Izuku Midoriya</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/izuku-midoriya-Cropped-2.jpg' /></figure><p>While the most logical choice for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-deku-most-likely-love-interests/\">Deku's future love interest</a> is Ochako Uraraka, that doesn't exactly mean that he and Shoto can't get together. At the moment, nothing concrete has happened between Deku and Ochako.</p><p>Deku, Bakugo, and Shoto are some of the most important protagonists of the show. Shoto and Deku know each other on a much more personal level than Deku and Bakugo, despite the past shared by the latter.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Fan Pick: Ochako Uraraka</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/uraraka.jpg' /></figure><p>A necessary candidate for pretty much any list of ships which includes fan picks, Ochako Uraraka can't go without being mentioned in these conversations. She's a fan favorite in the show, but aside from that, she's just such a kind person!</p><p>Ochako would be a great catch in the future for any character, but perhaps she could also help someone like Shoto work through a lot of his most pressing issues. At the very least, she would be there to listen as he figures things out for himself.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/my-hero-academia-deku-melissa-uraraka-ships/\">My Hero Academia: 5 Reasons Why Deku Should End Up With Melissa (&#38; 5 Reasons Why Uraraka Is Perfect For Him)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:30:17 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/My-Hero-Academia-5-Characters-Fans-Want-Shoto-To-End-Up-With-5-That-Are-More-Likely-featured-image.jpg","linkMd5":"08af5fa1ddf3ae32408f833498fc63cd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-357_0cce815d29be5d00.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":60142,"destBytes":60142,"author":"Cody ress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/uraraka.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn4@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-25-793_811db7932d774155.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389171},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Captain America: Marvel Introduces an All-New Iron Patriot | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-sharon-carter-new-iron-patriot/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Iron-Patriot-Captain-America.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: This article contains spoilers from <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/captain-america/\">Captain America</a> #22 by Ta-Nehisi Coates, Bob Quinn Matt Milla, and VC's Joe Caramagna, on sale now.</strong></em></p><p>In <em>Captain America</em>, Steve Rogers and his team are locked in a confrontation with the Power Elite, an organization made up of dangerous villains such as Alexa Lukin and the mutant Selene. The Power Elite has influence on the political stage, and they were even able to frame Captain America for the murder of General Ross. While Steve spent some time in prison for the crime, he was eventually freed by the Daughters of Liberty, a female team of superheroes which includes Misty Knight, Mockingbird, Toni Ho and Steve's longtime girlfriend, Sharon Carter, among others.</p><p>Now, Steve and his two partners, Sam Wilson and Bucky Barnes, have gone undercover in a small town controlled by the Power Elite to try and take the organization down. Their target is Selene, who has stolen a piece of Selene's soul. They are fighting to get it back, but the confrontation takes a turn for the worse.</p><p>Luckily, a new Iron Patriot shows up to lend Captain America a helping hand in<em> Captain America</em> #22.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Captain America: Did Marvel Just Introduce the New Howling Commandos?\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-new-howling-commandos/\">Captain America: Did Marvel Just Introduce The New Howling Commandos?</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Captain-America-22-Sharon-Carter-Iron-Patriot.jpg\"/></figure><p>In <em>Captain America</em> #22, Steve, Sam and Bucky are locked in a battle against Selene and her mind-controlled men in the small, Power Elite-ruled town of Adamsville, Ohio. The three superheroes take on a whole swarm of enemies on top of Selene, a powerful mutant who uses her abilities to gain the upper hand. Systematically, she knocks out both the Winter Soldier and the Falcon, until Captain America is her only opponent left. Steve gives everything he has in the fight against the mutant, but she proves too powerful.</p><p>She slices him and even bites him before knocking him out. Before she can consume Captain America's soul, a portal opens right above Selene, and a trio of reinforcements arrives in the form of the witch Agatha Harkness, Wakanda's own Shuri and Sharon Carter, who is now wearing the Iron Patriot armor.</p><p>How did Sharon end up with the armor? As Steve, Bucky and Sam fought Selene and the Power Elite, Sharon could do nothing but watch as they took on a dangerous enemy to reclaim her own soul. After all the time spent stuck on the sidelines, Sharon simply decides to take matters into her own hands, to fight for herself and what's rightfully hers. Instead of waiting and planning and letting others fight for her, she opts to get directly involved in the battle.</p><p>Without any sort of superpowers, Sharon is simply no match for the likes of Selene. Thankfully, she had a friend who can lend her the Iron Patriot armor: Dr. Toni Ho.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-star-infinity-stone-powerful-villain/\">Marvel's Most Dangerous Villain Just Became Even MORE Powerful</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/captain-america-iron-patriot-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>The Iron Patriot armor was first worn by Norman Osborn. After the events of <em>Secret Invasion</em>, which saw him emerge as a hero in the public's eye, Norman re-branded S.H.I.E.L.D. and appointed himself as its new leader. Wearing a red, white and blue Iron Man armor, Norman took on the identity of the Iron Patriot as a symbol of strength and belief for the American people.</p><p>Eventually, however, real heroes would come to wear that armor in the name of good: James \"Rhodey\" Rhodes suited up as the Iron Patriot before Toni Ho followed in his footsteps.</p><p>Since Toni is a member of the Daughters of Liberty alongside Sharon Carter, the suit was ready and on hand for Sharon to use. Oh, and the best part? When she shows up wearing her new suit ready to fight Selene, she borrows Captain America's famous Marvel Cinematic Universe line: \"I can do this all day.\"</p><p>Now, Sharon has joined the fight as the latest character to wear the Iron Patriot. If she is able to defeat Selene and get her soul back, then perhaps she will see the value in becoming a superhero herself. For the time being, we don't know if Sharon will keep being Iron Patriot, but if she does, Captain America and the Iron Patriot could become Marvel's next superhero duo.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Captain America Spent His Final Day Trying to Save [SPOILER] - And That's Important\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-final-day-mark-gruenwald-run/\">Captain America Spent His Final Day Trying To Save [SPOILER] - And That's Important</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 10:20:07 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Iron-Patriot-Captain-America.jpg","linkMd5":"7a90f2953cd41254268144aa39671264","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn68@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-11-418_a8ff47b2e150baf9.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":177652,"destBytes":177652,"author":"Ian Cardona","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Iron-Patriot-Captain-America.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn68@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-11-418_a8ff47b2e150baf9.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Captain-America-22-Sharon-Carter-Iron-Patriot.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-27-926_3bd569f3b30124fb.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/captain-america-iron-patriot-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn96@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-32-569_488a6327ebd578a7.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389185},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Frequency: Harmonix’s FIRST Game Paved the Way for Guitar Hero","link":"https://www.cbr.com/frequency-harmonix-first-game-paved-way-guitar-hero/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Frequency.jpg\"/></figure><p>Harmonix revolutionized the video game world when it released <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/guitar-hero/\">Guitar Hero</a></em> back in 2005, with music rhythm games becoming an overnight sensation, selling millions of units across the globe. While games like <em>Guitar Hero</em> brought music rhythm games and Harmonix into the mainstream, the video game company already had a few music-based titles under its belt by 2005.</p><p>A forgotten rhythm game, <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/frequency/\">Frequency</a>,</em> was Harmonix's first attempt in mixing the two mediums. Today, <em>Frequency</em> has fallen into obscurity, even though it laid the groundwork for many popular music games people love today.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/haunting-ground-disturbing-ps2-game/\">Haunting Ground: The Most Disturbing PS2 Game You've Never Played</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/frequency-2.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>Frequency</em> debuted on the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/playstation/\">PlayStation</a> 2 in 2001. The game had an extremely original concept that many viewed as experimental at the time: players were thrown into a psychedelic musical tunnel in the shape of an octagon, where every segment of the octagon represented specific musical instruments and button commands. Each section threw elaborate button sequences players would need to mimic with their controller. These button commands would turn into instrumental melodies once the player matched the commands with the correct pattern, and they would have to perform each button command with every section within the tunnel to create a song. Players would unlock new songs (which represent the levels) by completing every section of the octagon correctly.</p><p>Harmonix somehow managed to get big-name bands and musicians of the time to lend their music to <em>Frequency</em>. Bands like No Doubt and Fear Factory, along with DJs such as Paul Oakenfold and The Crystal Method, all agreed to put their music in the game. This was a huge selling point for <em>Frequency,</em> with many gamers looking forward to the experimental title.
