Some musical acts even made exclusive tracks for the game, exciting music and video game fans alike. <em>Frequency</em> was so abstract that people couldn't help but become obsessed with the games obscure premise.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tony-hawks-pro-skater-2-best-in-series/\">Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 Is The Best Game in The Series - Here's Why</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/frequency-gameplay-ps2-image.jpg\"/></figure><p>While <em>Frequency</em> enjoyed some success, it didn't achieve the legendary status <em>Guitar Hero</em> did a few years later. The game was very ahead of its time and flew over the heads of many video game fans. <em>Frequency</em>'s unconventional gameplay mechanics and trippy nature may have turned off casual gamers. Still, it did sell well enough to warrant a sequel, <em>Amplitude,</em> which focused more on rock music instead of EDM. Despite positive word of mouth, the series became an underground hit instead of a mainstream blockbuster.</p><p>Although <em>Frequency</em> didn't sell as well as Harmonix would have liked, the game did set the groundwork for its future games like <em>Guitar Hero</em> and <em>Rock Band</em>. There is a good chance that these iconic franchises wouldn't exist if it weren't for <em>Frequency</em>. The title's experimental gameplay was a little too avant-garde at the time but would become accepted after <em>Guitar Hero</em> improved upon its core foundation. <em>Frequency</em> still holds up today and gives gamers a primitive look at <em>Guitar Hero'</em>s gameplay structure. Even though <em>Frequency</em> is inferior to most modern music rhythm games, it is still worth checking out just to see how far the genre has come.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/rival-schools-forgotten-capcom-fighter-explained/\">Rival Schools: The Beloved Fighter That Capcom Forgot About, Explained</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 16:15:43 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Frequency.jpg","linkMd5":"950c6f20ac1230ab821642aeacb6061c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn84@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-09-284_4c55d7e71b901af2.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":96902,"destBytes":96902,"author":"Zack Millsap","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Frequency.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn84@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-09-284_4c55d7e71b901af2.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/frequency-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-24-491_726e5987cf151c2e.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/frequency-gameplay-ps2-image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn55@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-22-267_fd55fc137224c27f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389179},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Gotham Knights: Why Batman Should Be the Game's TRUE Villain","link":"https://www.cbr.com/gotham-knights-batman-should-be-villain/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/gotham-knights-heroes.jpg\"/></figure><p>Debuting at DC FanDome, the upcoming <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/batman\">Batman</a> video game,<em> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/gotham-knights/\">Gotham Knights</a></em>, will feature four playable characters. Surprisingly, however, Batman isn't one of them.</p><p>While it doesn't appear the game will be a direct sequel to <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/batman-arkham/\">Batman: Arkham Knight</a></em>, it opens with the status quo that game <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/video-game-endings-worth-it-not/\">established with its ending</a>: Batman is dead following the destruction of Wayne Manor. But that doesn't mean the Caped Crusader won't have a role in the <em>Gotham Knights</em> story.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/gotham-knights-jim-lee-alex-sinclair-concept-art/\">Gotham Knights: Jim Lee, Alex Sinclair Drop Concept Art for the Bat-Family Game</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Gotham-Knights-Court-of-Owls-talon-reveal.jpg\"/></figure><p>In the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-gotham-knights-wb-games-montreal-dc-fandome/\">announcement trailer</a>, the main villain is revealed to be the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/gotham-knights-court-of-owls-explained/\">Court of Owls</a>, a secret society that's shaped Gotham's history. One way they've imposed their will on the city is through their foot soldiers, the Talons. Batman becoming one of them would be a bold move, but not unprecedented in the source material: They've recruited from the Bat-Family before.</p><p>After Batman discovered the Court in the comics, he faced off with the Talons for the first time. He was nearly defeated by Talon William Cobb, who claimed to have killed many members of the Wayne family. Cobb also turned out to be Dick Grayson's great-grandfather. Cobb felt betrayed by Grayson's membership in the Bat-Family because he intended for him to become a Talon; therefore, he vowed to kill his great-grandson.</p><p>A battle between the two happened in the 2012 crossover \"Night of the Owls,\" which had the entire Bat-Family fighting Talons. <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/nightwing\">Nightwing</a> was able to outsmart his murderous ancestor and freeze him, putting him out of commission for a time.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/gotham-knights-gameplay-batgirl-red-robin-mr-freeze/\">Gotham Knights Gameplay Footage Pits Batgirl and Red Robin Against Mr. Freeze</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Nightwing-Dick-Grayson-Talon.jpg\"/></figure><p>Grayson avoided becoming a Talon during his first encounter with the Court, but he was eventually blackmailed into becoming one when the Court planted a bomb inside Damian Wayne. Nightwing also became a Talon during his days as the amnesiac Ric Grayson, when Cobb was able to hypnotize him into the role.</p><p>Beyond being a good nod to the source material, the Talons recruiting from the Bat-Family would be consistent with what <em>Gotham Knight</em> represents for the franchise. A new generation of protectors having to step up in Batman's absence is a novel idea. Gamers played the vast majority of the <em>Arkham</em> series as a Batman who worked alone.</p><p>Putting players in control of Batman's allies and utilizing co-op as a core mechanic shakes things up considerably. The Bat-Family will have to work together with the whole city against them, including the police -- whom Batman warns his proteges not to trust after Jim Gordon dies.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"http://cbr.com/dc-fandome-every-trailer-teaser-released-event/\">DC FanDome: Every Trailer &#38; Teaser Released at the Digital Event</a></span></p><p>With the Bat-Family already fighting overwhelming odds, adding a corrupted version of their mentor to the mix would really raise the stakes of their mission. Having to fight to save Gotham and free Batman from the clutches of the Court would make their victory at the end of the game more impressive and open the door for Batman to be involved in future DLC or a sequel.</p><p>It would also be a huge shock for players who've spent so much time playing as the Caped Crusader over the years. Batman has been the central hero of  the <em>Arkham </em>and <em><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/injustice\">Injustice</a> </em>games, taking on his rogues gallery and the corrupted heroes of the <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/justice-league\">Justice League</a>. To see him turn evil and have to fight him could be an unforgettable gameplay experience, if done right.</p><p>WB Montreal has promised there's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/gotham-knights-game-everything-we-know/\">more mystery</a> to <em>Gotham Knights</em> beyond the Owls appearance. Batman's fate, whether he becomes a Talon or not, will likely be part of that. Batman as a member of the Court would be a huge challenge for the Bat-Family and players alike. It would help this new generation of Batman games come into its own and break out of the <em>Arkham</em> series' shadow.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Keep Reading: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/suicide-squad-kill-justice-league-shares-universe-batman-arkham-games/\">Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League Shares a Universe With the Batman: Arkham Games</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 10:15:23 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/gotham-knights-heroes.jpg","linkMd5":"a05cc83fd1b20dddae969c2af101b8e2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-09-347_d0b478ca9359a16f.webp","destWidth":1599,"destHeight":799,"sourceBytes":128060,"destBytes":128060,"author":"Robert Curran","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/gotham-knights-heroes.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-09-347_d0b478ca9359a16f.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Gotham-Knights-Court-of-Owls-talon-reveal.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn7@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-32-566_f5d02b2501847d6d.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Nightwing-Dick-Grayson-Talon.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn31@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-28-654_f30e576b948d1514.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389185},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Captain America’s Biggest Endgame Moment Pales Compared to... Mr. Rogers’?","link":"https://www.cbr.com/thor-mr-rogers-lifts-mjolnir/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mister-rogers-thor.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/thor/\">Thor</a>'s iconic hammer, Mjolnir, is somewhat of a mystery. Its enchantment states that the hammer can only be lifted by those who are \"worthy.\" Yet worthiness is pretty vague when it comes <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-thanos-mjolnir-infinity-upgrades/\">to those who can</a> and cannot lift Mjolnir. Recently, Mjolnir's ambiguous enchantment may have been made a little clearer by none other than Fred Rogers.</p><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/ByTwistwood\">Canadian illustrator Twistwood</a> shared a tweet in March 2019 adapting Matthew Wisner's script, depicting an interaction between Mr. Rogers and Thor, into a comic. In the comic, Mr. Rogers inquires into the heaviness of Thor's hammer, and before the thunder god can blink, Rogers is lifting Mjolnir himself. Mr. Rogers then muses on how objects can be heavier for some individuals than others, since everyone is different and special in their own ways. In fact, those that may not be able to lift Mjolnir might be able to do other things that Thor cannot.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/what-nick-fury-whispered-thor-unworthy/\">Thor: Three Words Hold More Power Over Marvel's Thunder God Than Anything Else</a></span></p><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://twitter.com/ByTwistwood/status/1109936608122454020\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><p>Mr. Rogers' wholesome words provoke much thought around who is worthy of wielding Mjolnir. Clearly Odin, who was present for Mjolnir's creation and enchantment, is able to wield the mighty hammer. Additionally, Bor, Thor's grandfather, has held Mjolnir as well.</p><p>Outside of Thor's family, however, the first person to wield Mjolnir was <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-beta-ray-bill-got-weirder-and-powerful/\">Beta Ray Bill</a>, in <em>The Mighty Thor </em>#337 by Walter Simonson. Bill is an alien being who befriended Thor at the beginning of Simonson's legendary <em>Thor</em> run. Thor and Bill bonded over their worthiness and the Asgardians even forged Bill his own hammer, Stormbreaker.</p><p>Several Marvel heroes have lifted Mjolnir as well. Most prominently, Thor's fellow Avenger, <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/captain-america\">Captain America</a>, has wielded the hammer on several occasions. Cap's worthiness, combined with his iconic leadership and soldier's attitude, created a unique bond between Thor and the Sentinel of Liberty.</p><p>The mantle of Thor has also been held by Eric Masterson, a construction worker who Odin merged with Thor. Masterson acted as Thor until the two were separated once again, eventually becoming the hero known as Thunderstrike. Additionally, when Thor became unworthy at the end of Jason Aaron's <em><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/original-sin\">Original Sin</a></em>, Mjolnir was <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/how-jane-foster-became-the-mighty-thor/\">claimed by Jane Foster</a>. Jane was the nurse of Dr. Donald Blake, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-9-reintroduces-god-of-thunder-human-host-donald-blake/\">Thor's original human host</a>. As Thor, Foster reminded the Odinson what it meant to be worthy.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/why-jane-foster-more-worthy-than-thor/\">Why Jane Foster Is More Worthy Than Thor Odinson</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Thor-Jane-Foster.jpg\"/></figure><p>Some characters outside of the Marvel Universe have also been worthy of Mjolnir. In <em>Marvel vs. DC </em>#2, <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/wonder-woman\">Wonder Woman</a> encountered Thor's enchanted hammer. The Amazonian princess was startled to find herself able to wield Mjolnir, briefly commanding Thor's power. In <em>JLA/Avengers </em>#4, by Kurt Busiek and George Perez, <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/superman\">Superman </a>was also briefly able to lift Mjolnir. During a massive battle, Thor momentarily lifted the hammer's enchantment, enabling the Man of Steel to wield its power.</p><p>Instances of characters outside of the Marvel Universe wielding Mjolnir are generally non-canon. For this reason, current <em>Thor</em> writer <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mister-rogers-worthy-mjolnir-donny-cates-thor-fan-comic-marvel-canon/\">Donny Cates' response to Twistwood's comic</a> is pretty astounding. In a tweet on Aug. 16, Cates simply stated, \"This is now officially canon.\" This response was clearly a lighthearted display of appreciation for the comic. Yet, canonizing Mr. Rogers' worthiness adds an extra dimension to Mjolnir's enchantment.</p><p>While some characters like Captain America or Wonder Woman share Thor's ability to carry Mjolnir, the weight of the hammer may be more difficult for characters like Superman. Still, those who are unworthy may possess abilities that the worthy do not, explaining why many iconic heroes are unworthy of lifting Mjolnir.</p><p>The wholesome nature of Mr. Rogers' worthiness adds a sense of comfort to Mjolnir's enchantment.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/thor-butchered-marvel-god-galactus/\">Thor Just BUTCHERED One of Marvel's Most Powerful Gods</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 03:30:50 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mister-rogers-thor.jpg","linkMd5":"5c35f0b3c118a285fec6eea70dec0f34","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-680_32a4c78ff830b923.webp","destWidth":1500,"destHeight":750,"sourceBytes":155982,"destBytes":155982,"author":"Nabeel Gaber","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mister-rogers-thor.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-680_32a4c78ff830b923.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Thor-Jane-Foster.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn75@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-21-106_a571b3fe49c1aae6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389186},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"10 Things Psycho-Pass Does Better Than Other Cyberpunk Anime","link":"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-reasons-better-other-cyberpunk-anime/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/10-Things-Psycho-Pass-Does-Better-Than-Other-Cyberpunk-Anime-featured-image.jpg\"/></figure><p>Bright pink and blue neon lights. An overcrowded city at night. The typical cyberpunk protagonist steps one foot into a rather sizable puddle of water on a beaten-down street. They're chasing after someone as the camera quickly swaps angles into the next shot, one of them on a manhunt eventually going down a long alleyway, only to find their suspect looking for a futile escape from a complete dead-ended street.</p><p>Those familiar with cyberpunk/neo-noir media have seen this setup so many times before. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/psycho-pass/\"><em>Psycho-Pass</em></a> doesn't completely abandon these all-too-familiar tropes the viewers have come to expect from this <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/cyberpunk-2077-why-be-hyped-worried/\">subgenre of sci-fi media</a>, but it does offer a fresh take on the concept of a futuristic crime drama.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-best-episodes-imdb/\">Psycho-Pass: 10 Best Episodes According To IMDb</a></span></p><p>The anime manages to circumvent quite a few recognizable tropes of the style in a manner worthy of praise for its originality.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>It Doesn't Just Emulate Blade Runner</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/blade-runner-film.jpg' /></figure><p>For as many similarities as it could have aesthetically to <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/blade-runner-anime-theories-fan-series/\">Blade Runner</a></em>, <em>Psycho-Pass</em> decided to focus on the \"what-if's\" of technology in different aspects of society advancing further. For example, <em>Blade Runner</em> has a heavy focus on automating the bottom-line of workers tasked with more laborious and dangerous jobs in the distant future of November 2019 (far-out, huh?).</p><p>Meanwhile,<em> Psycho-Pass</em> has a heavy angle of automation in the social roles of government and crime-fighting. It chooses not to focus on androids and the concept of sentience almost <em>at all</em> as a theme.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>It Doesn't Just Emulate Ghost In The Shell Either</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/ghost-in-the-shell-anime.jpg' /></figure><p>Inspector Akane Tsunemori is by no means a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/major-makoto-kusanagi-outfits-ranked/\">Major Kusanagi</a>-style badass with an iron mind and will. She isn't even old enough to drink. Akane very much feels like a naive early 20s adult who is learning to grasp the basics of the Ministry of Welfare's Public Safety Bureau (MWPSB) as she is thrust into new situations fresh out of her Sibyl career assessment and subsequent schooling.</p><p>This is in harsh contrast to Kusanagi's character, specifically in the 1995 movie of <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ghost-in-the-shell-best-vs-worst-cyberpunk-anime/\">Ghost In The Shell</a></em>. Kusanagi struggles to identify herself, being human born, with the functions and behavioral inclinations of humanity as a whole.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Its Dystopic Leanings Are In A Creative New Direction</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-brains.jpg' /></figure><p>The cruxes of many plots within cyberpunk media rely on being <em>just</em> futuristic enough to follow the automation of the late 20th century workplaces to fully automized endpoints. To a lesser degree, they explore how that would heighten and change the nature of corruption inside governments to very anarcho-capitalist endpoints, in accordance with the author's views.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/anime-science-fiction-scifi-hilarious-dark/\">5 Sci-Fi Anime That Are Hilarious (&#38; 5 That Are Really Dark)</a></span></p><p>However, <em>Psycho-Pass</em> as a concept chooses to focus on the direct convergence of automation and how the nature of governing a civilian body is handled in a far-future perspective. This includes how an individual is tasked with social responsibility (formerly \"jobs\" and \"careers\") and how crime is prosecuted. A major theme of this show is the offloading of these responsibilities from the civilian population almost entirely, and the growing pains from a very rocky implementation.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>It Takes A Risk Using More Fantastical Future-Tech</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-dominator-lethal-eliminator-mode-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>The Dominator hue-assessment gun is the 2nd most important tech from the show. To offload more complex ethical decision making on the behalf of the Inspectors, Dominators go through a connected assessment of mental \"hue\" for those individuals that the gun is pointed at.</p><p>This sits close to a conversation about what differentiates \"Enforcers,\" the \"bloodhounds\" of the police force (who often have cloudy hues themselves), from Inspectors. The Sibyl System prefers to keep the latter unclouded and performing checks on the mental state and current wills of said Enforcers as their main task. The Sibyl System itself is what decides almost everything about a person's propensity for in day to day life, including assessments as a \"latent criminal,\" as well as different career leanings a person may have.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>It's Just As Much Of A Psychological-Thriller</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Psycho-Pass.jpg' /></figure><p>Contrary to sweeping shots of a strictly 1980s envisioning of a future taking place in the <em>now</em> current day, positing philosophical questions about AI and sentience, <em>Psycho-Pass</em> is more interested in providing a psychological thriller story about how MWPSB members working under the Sibyl System tackle crime.</p><p>This show shows how some learn to skirt the bounds of the system in new forms of organized crime. <em>Psycho-Pass </em>highlights how members of the MWPSB (namely Shinya Kogami) are affected personally, instead of posing questions of AI's ability to become sentient, an idea more commonplace in other entries of the genre.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>It's More Of A Crime Drama Than A Cyberpunk Anime</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/crime-coefficient-execution-status-psycho-pass-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-times-shogo-makishima-was-right-vs-wrong-comparison/\">Shinya Kogami's backstory</a> may be among the most gripping pieces of this universe's story. Once an Inspector, you come to learn about a case that caused his Hue to become so clouded that he was demoted to an Enforcer, and why the case took such a hold on him.</p><p>Unlike the psychological thriller angle mentioned prior, <em>Psycho-Pass</em> also gives due time to the case Kogami never gave up. His eventual findings and reopening of the case become one roller coaster of a plot point leading back into the show's initially contextless opening sequence.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>It Makes You Legitimately Question Who Is Right In The Sibyl System Situation</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-incorrect-crime-assessment-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>This show poses hard-to-answer questions about behaviors of those under extreme mental stress, combined with the ability for their technology to detect said stress.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-akane-sibyl-system-times-right-worked/\">Psycho-Pass: 5 Times Akane Was Right (&#38; 5 Times The Sibyl System Was Right)</a></span></p><p>After isolating future Japan's borders so none may leave or enter, in order for the Sibyl System to avoid overloading itself (and also avoid complicated international political situations), it's difficult to find an alternative to this dystopic automation of a justice system. Given that everyone is far too in the know about each other's mental \"hue\" states and the fact that some people are fine with this system,<em> </em>it's removal is complicated by those who prefer it. If it were overthrown, what choices and chaos do that present to this society's situation?</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>It's Grounded In More Relatable Problems Of Today's Society</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kogami-speech-psycho-pass-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p><em>Psycho-Pass</em> lives and breathes the problem of how to deal with mental illness and instability as a society. It also tackles the current political division of how an authoritarian style of policing <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-things-from-this-future-want-dont-want-alternate-reality-anime-dystopia/\">should be implemented</a>, and how many freedoms and rights a civilian body is willing to give up for peace of mind.</p><p>As far-flung into the future with the technological backdrop and metaphors as this anime might be, this cuts to the heart of proposed issues of crime in society. It attempts to address it at a proposed mental instability root in its own future-fantasy sort of way.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>You Witness The Inner Workings Of The Future Police Forces</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-scene-anime.jpg' /></figure><p>In how many cyberpunk anime do viewers become intimately familiar with the functioning of the justice system right off the bat? In fact, that is the core to understanding the motivations of each of the main characters in the show.</p><p>While the <em>true</em> inner functions of the Sibyl System are kept hidden until the latter third of <em>Psycho-Pass</em>, the guiding narrative functions by bringing viewers along with different Inspectors and Enforcers. The characters face moral dilemmas of a futuristic police force's function in executing the will and decisions of the Sibyl System and its assessments of Crime Coefficients and \"hues\" of various civilians in the show.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>It Adds A Splash Of Horror To It All</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-akane.jpg' /></figure><p>For the lighter notes of the show (like Akane and Masaoka going through CommuField cosplay meetups for information), there are also <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-most-sadistic-villains-ranked/\">rather gruesome ones</a>. An example being when Akane is cornered into disbelief when a clear criminal kidnaps her friend and threatens to kill her right in front of her eyes, all while her Dominator refuses to allow her to stun or kill the man.</p><p>So Akane really has to watch her friend die. To make matters worse, this case actually requires her to relive those memories while connected to a machine, so that they can put an image of the man's face together. Don't get it twisted; while this world seems almost free of violent danger, it becomes apparent that it is not.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/psycho-pass-akane-sibyl-system-times-right-worked/\">Psycho-Pass: 10 Real-Life Philosophies That Influenced The Show</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 16:30:33 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/10-Things-Psycho-Pass-Does-Better-Than-Other-Cyberpunk-Anime-featured-image.jpg","linkMd5":"3291c0cb53de560f12a07c7348bd3294","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-499_bbcca470ac2ebd7b.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":134074,"destBytes":134074,"author":"Chris Evans","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/10-Things-Psycho-Pass-Does-Better-Than-Other-Cyberpunk-Anime-featured-image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn79@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-499_bbcca470ac2ebd7b.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/blade-runner-film.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn51@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-28-654_a1ff2ee0ec99a43d.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/ghost-in-the-shell-anime.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-21-158_1059b5d88fa2dd43.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-brains.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn72@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-23-247_70e299afbe5937bc.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-dominator-lethal-eliminator-mode-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn35@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-21-113_17795854f4018dcb.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Psycho-Pass.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn63@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-23-174_929b33c947cc6ae8.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/crime-coefficient-execution-status-psycho-pass-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn95@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-21-152_2503630feed6c428.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-incorrect-crime-assessment-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn51@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-26-292_e6397e33400b437f.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kogami-speech-psycho-pass-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-29-085_6f6e0a021cd9428b.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-scene-anime.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn23@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-31-044_67faafb3cd66fb66.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/psycho-pass-akane.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn52@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-24-440_d3a3f517a7f0ad60.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389187},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"10 Games With Combat Like Ghost Of Tsushima You Can Also Play On PS4","link":"https://www.cbr.com/games-like-ghost-of-tsushima-on-ps4/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/got-fi.jpg\"/></figure><p>While this current gaming generation is coming to a close, developers are not done squeezing every bit of juice they can out of the old consoles. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ghost-of-tsushima-hilarious-logic-memes/\">Nothing exemplifies this more than Sucker Punch Productions' <em>Ghost of Tsushima</em></a>, an open-world samurai epic which proves to be one of the most beautiful games of such an immense scope.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/crazy-things-before-stop-playing-ghost-of-tsushima/\">10 Crazy Things You Have To Do Before You Stop Playing Ghost Of Tsushima</a></span></p><p>While the world is an alluring factor, plenty of fans are equally enthralled with the swordplay and stealth mechanics. For anybody itching for combat of a similar vein after beating Jin Sakai's adventure, any of the ten games below may help. They are not all carbon copies, but they generally involve swords, stealth, and reacting to enemy moves with quick timing.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Assassin's Creed II</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/maxresdefault-1.jpg' /></figure><p>The recent PlayStation 4 exclusives draws<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-assassins-creed-fan-art/\"> many comparisons to early <em>Assassin's Creed </em>games</a>, particularly the second numbered entry in the franchise. This is a compliment, since this is where the series hit a stride. Fans have been itching for Ubisoft to tackle feudal Japan since the series' inception, so they are pleased Sucker Punch took the initiative. Like <em>Ghost</em>, the older games' combat is based off of counter-attacks. It is not as refined as the new game, but combat is only a small portion of the franchise.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Dark Souls</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kaathe-abyss-dark-souls.jpg' /></figure><p>FromSoftware crafts some of the most difficult games in the action/adventure genre, so expect a significant challenge when jumping into <em>Dark Souls</em>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dark-souls-games-action-rpg-franchise/\">10 Games To Play If You Love Dark Souls</a></span></p><p>While both games involve swords, the similarities admittedly do not reach much deeper than that and a focus on blocking. <em>Dark Souls</em> also features more in-depth RPG mechanics and a greater variety of weaponry. The animations also are not as smooth and fighting is slower overall.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Arkham Series</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/arkham-knight-gotham.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/best-batman-quotes-arkham-games/\">Rocksteady's <em>Arkham </em>trilogy</a> takes a relatively simple combo system and gives it renewed depth by increasing the focus on split-second reactions to enemy attacks. When the signal appears on screen, players have barely a moment to counter, lest their combo be broken. This mechanic makes for an addictive combat loop, almost feeling like a rhythm game. A similar desire for continuous counters is in <em>Ghost of Tsushima</em>, as players avoid damage of any kind to fill up the Ghost Meter.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Nioh</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Nioh-2.jpg' /></figure><p>Like <em>Dark Souls</em>, <em>Nioh</em> will destroy and humble anybody who touches it. The similarities between it and <em>Ghost of Tsushima</em> says a lot about why Sucker Punch's recent title resonates with so many. It takes the fun parts of many of these critically revered, yet brutally difficult games and makes them more accessible. As a reminder, anybody wanting an increased challenge out of <em>Ghost</em> can always turn up the difficulty to lethal mode.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>For Honor</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/for-honor-header.jpg' /></figure><p>This Ubisoft game came out in 2017 and still receives regular support. Players engage in close-quarters, brutal swordplay with either AI in the single-player mode or with other players. The one on one bouts are incredibly in-depth, requiring the player to select their stance and move set based on opponents' visual cues. Anyone enamored with <em>Ghost of Tsushima's </em>duels owes it to themselves to try out <em>For Honor</em>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/star-wars-jedi-fallen-order-merrin-cal.jpg' /></figure><p>While <em>Ghost of Tsushima's </em>combat borrows ever-so light elements from <em>Dark Souls</em> and <em>Bloodborne</em>, <em>Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order</em> wears the influence far more visibly on its sleeve. Mainstays of the genre like respawning enemies and campfires make their way into one of the<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-jedi-fallen-order-fan-created-art-pieces/\"> most critically revered <em>Star Wars</em> games of the generation</a>. Considering samurai films' influence on George Lucas when creating his opus, it only seems right for a game in the franchise to make it on this list.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Sekiro-shadows-die-twice.jpg' /></figure><p>Some consider <em>Sekiro</em> to be even more difficult than <em>Dark Souls</em> and <em>Bloodborne</em>, making it a truly harrowing experience for those brave enough to confront it. Unlike its brethren, stealth plays a key role in the gameplay, making it even closer to <em>Ghost of Tsushima</em>. One won't be able to take out entire areas stealthily like in the Sucker Punch game, but it does give an upper hand when beginning combat encounters. In a game as tough as this, any assistance helps.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Witcher 3</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/The-Witcher-3-Geralt-Investigating-Monster-Contract.jpg' /></figure><p><em>The Witcher 3</em> is an incredibly massive game. Even five years after release, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/rpgs-you-should-play-after-ff7-remake-final-fantasy-kingdom-hearts-paper-mario/\">few other RPGs hope to match its scope</a>. The combat is not necessarily the weakest part of the game, but it is mostly negligible when compared to the stellar writing and quests.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/witcher-best-cosplay-geralt-of-rivia-yennefer-netflix/\">10 Best Witcher Cosplays You Have To See To Believe</a></span></p><p>However, it certainly gets the job done. Geralt's dance with the blade reminds one of a primitive version of <em>Ghost of Tsushima's </em>combat.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Bloodborne</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/bloodborne-hunter.jpg' /></figure><p>Even among the almost universally beloved output of FromSoftware since 2009's <em>Demon's Souls</em>, <em>Bloodborne</em> stands out as a particularly venerated title. The PS4 exclusive smooths out the trademark combat and adds a gun to the mix which can be used to parry attacks if timed correctly. It encourages more aggressive tactics than its contemporaries. Recognizing visual cues from enemies is key to victory, much like in <em>Ghost of Tsushima.</em></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Marvel's Spider-Man</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Spider-Man-PS4.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/10-things-you-didnt-know-about-spider-man-ps4s-side-characters/\">Insomniac Games' <em>Marvel's Spider-Man</em> was a massive hit upon its 2018 release</a> for how faithfully it captured the iconic comic book character's spirit. The combat makes it onto the list because of its similarities to the <em>Arkham </em>games' combat. Like the <em>Batman</em> trilogy and <em>Ghost of Tsushima</em>, stealth also plays a role in the gameplay, with Spider-Man sometimes having the option to silently web up foes while perched up on high. Unlike <em>Ghost</em>, it is not a moral quandary or internal conflict Peter deals with throughout the course of the game.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Next:<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ghost-of-tsushima-beginner-mistakes-you-dont-want-to-make/\"> 10 Beginner Mistakes You Don't Want To Make In Ghost Of Tsushima</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 18:30:28 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/got-fi.jpg","linkMd5":"916ad574cfcb7aa6d167ffec53b5f7ff","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-10-321_ca03dc0f14e47611.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":252542,"destBytes":252542,"author":"Jason Wojnar","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/got-fi.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-10-321_ca03dc0f14e47611.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/maxresdefault-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn80@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-28-241_23fd36b9e6b4fca7.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kaathe-abyss-dark-souls.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn92@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-21-169_7600b9fc901fb4da.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/arkham-knight-gotham.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-31-151_e305d1d40a107200.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Nioh-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn80@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-31-565_d3c26b1cf532911a.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/for-honor-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-24-906_c962278be3b77a54.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/star-wars-jedi-fallen-order-merrin-cal.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn16@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-31-001_c0ef8b1e90444f34.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Sekiro-shadows-die-twice.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn20@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-21-201_da21f7e22c008e0a.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/The-Witcher-3-Geralt-Investigating-Monster-Contract.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-26-990_66a0626cd0357394.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/bloodborne-hunter.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-24-719_212b792d51b90f87.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Spider-Man-PS4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn67@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-26-482_b59c8e82d276dee8.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389174},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"5 X-Men Villains Who Can Defeat The Justice League (& 5 Who Would Be Defeated By The League)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-villains-vs-justice-league-win-lose-comparison/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/X-Men-Villains-vs-Justice-League.jpg\"/></figure><p>The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Justice-League/\">Justice League</a> is the DC Universe’s premier super-team, comprised of all the heavy hitters like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Superman/\">Superman</a>, <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/tag/Batman/\">Batman</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Wonder-Woman/\">Wonder Woman</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/The-Flash/\">The Flash</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Green-Lantern/\">Green Lantern</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Aquaman/\">Aquaman</a>, and the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Martian-Manhunter/\">Martian Manhunter</a>. They’re usually the Earth’s last line of defense against cosmic threats, and considering their track record, they’ve done very well in that regard.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/justice-league-villains-vs-avengers-who-would-win/\">5 Justice League Villains That Could Beat The Avengers (&#38; 5 The Avengers Could Beat)</a></span></p><p>Then again, they’ve never gone up against the villains of the X-Men, those dastardly malefactors who make pursuing Professor X’s dream of peace between humans and mutants difficult to achieve. Although there are some<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-xmen-villain-based-on-zodiac/\"> X-Men villains</a> the Justice League can handle soundly, there are some that would definitely be able to defeat them.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>DEFEAT THE LEAGUE: THE SHADOW KING</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/shadow-king-display.jpg' /></figure><p>A psionic being that resides on the astral plane, the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shadow-king-15-things-you-should-know/\">Shadow King</a> feeds on the dark side of human consciousness. Having existed since the dawn of time, the Shadow King knows all about manipulating minds, even those of powerful beings like mutants, as he did during the Muir Island Saga.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/telepaths-marvel-universe-ranked/\">The 10 Most Powerful Telepaths In The Marvel Universe, Ranked</a></span></p><p>Looking at the Justice League’s roster, it’s entirely conceivable that the Shadow King could infect any or all of their minds and commandeer them to do his will. None of them have sufficient psychic training to resist a being of the Shadow King’s power. Even the Martian Manhunter’s formidable mental powers are infinitesimal compared to the Shadow King!</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>THE LEAGUE WOULD DEFEAT: MAGNETO</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/X-Men-Magneto-using-powers.jpg' /></figure><p>The Master of Magnetism is a formidable opponent to be sure, as multiple iterations of the X-Men can attest to. His command over magnetic waves not only gives him control over all things metal, but with enough concentration, can also give him control over the Earth’s magnetic fields.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-heroes-magneto-would-love-hate/\">5 DC Heroes Magneto Would Get Along With (&#38; 5 He Would Hate)</a></span></p><p>Despite his ability to fight off multiple X-Men and Avengers at the same time, he’d be hard-pressed to fight off the Justice League. It’s entirely possible that the League’s heavy hitters could keep him occupied long enough for the Flash to steal <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/facts-magnetos-helmet/\">his helmet</a>, leaving him open to a debilitating psychic attack from the Martian Manhunter.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>DEFEAT THE LEAGUE: CASSANDRA NOVA</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Cassandra-Nova-in-New-X-Men.jpg' /></figure><p>The evil twin of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-professor-charles-xavier-things-didnt-know/\">Professor Charles Xavier</a>, Cassandra Nova is his ideological opposite. Possessed of immense psychic power, she’s utterly convinced she must destroy her brother and everything he holds dear, which explains her belief in violence and genocide. She was infamously responsible for sending an army of Sentinels to destroy the mutant nation of Genosha, resulting in the deaths of sixteen million people.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-marvel-cassandra-nova-awful-acts/\">X-Men: The 10 Worst Things Cassandra Nova Has Done To The Marvel Universe</a></span></p><p>Cassandra Nova’s list of abilities is beyond extensive, including telepathy, telekinesis, DNA manipulation, intangibility, and immunity to magic. Quite simply, her power may be beyond what even the Justice League could handle.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>THE LEAGUE WOULD DEFEAT: APOCALYPSE</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Apocalypse-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Touted as the world’s first mutant, En Sabah Nur first rose to prominence in ancient times, having been raised by an Egyptian tribe that dedicated itself to Darwinian principles of survival. Over the millennia and with the aid of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ranking-marvel-strongest-celestials-mcu/\">Celestial</a> technology, the being known as Apocalypse manipulated human history to ensure that only the strong survived.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-dc-villains-vs-apocalypse-who-would-win-lose/\">X-Men: 5 DC Villains Apocalypse Would Defeat (&#38; 5 He Would Lose To)</a></span></p><p>In fairness, a battle with the Justice League could very well go in Apocalypse’s favor. However, his stamina in battle is directly related to his ability to regenerate, which often needs prolonged bouts of catatonia to be fully effective. It’s entirely conceivable that the Justice League could wear Apocalypse down enough to exhaust him, earning them the victory.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>DEFEAT THE LEAGUE: VULCAN</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/vulcan-header.jpg' /></figure><p>Vulcan’s fraternal relationship to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-xmen-reasons-cyclops-havok-smartest-summers-brother/\">Cyclops and Havok</a> was a well-guarded secret. As a Summers boy, Gabriel can absorb and transmit energy, though on a much grander scale than either of his brothers. Vulcan’s abilities allow him to project energy at the cosmic level, create force fields, resist psychic assaults, and even bend reality to his will.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-vulcan-third-summers-brother/\">X-Men: 10 Things Fans Should Know About Vulcan, The Third Summers Brother</a></span></p><p>He’s used his abilities to conquer the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shi-ar-strongest-most-powerful-ranked/\">Shi’ar Empire</a> at least once, and a being of this power would definitely give the League a run for their money. Superman, Wonder Woman, and the Martian Manhunter would find it difficult to make any headway against Vulcan, and unless Batman can figure out a way to de-power him, this battle’s going to the Summers brother.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>THE LEAGUE WOULD DEFEAT: DARK BEAST</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Dark-Beast.jpg' /></figure><p>A refuge from the few <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-xmen-age-apocalypse-aged-well-poorly/\">Age of Apocalypse</a></em>, the Dark Beast is an evil version of Hank McCoy, with all his scientific prowess and genius-level intellect squarely aimed at fulfilling his own nefarious agenda. Through his experiments, he’s managed to create hordes of genetically enhanced soldiers, advanced weaponry, and has concocted wickedly successful plots against the X-Men. As formidable as he is, the League would be able to defeat the Dark Beast. Although he may have support from his inventions and potential soldier-slaves, Batman would be able to anticipate his strategies and prepare for them, allowing the League to take the win.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>DEFEAT THE LEAGUE: PROTEUS</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Proteus-feature.jpg' /></figure><p>The son of longtime X-Men ally <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/house-x-moira-mactaggert-moments/\">Moira MacTaggert,</a> Kevin was born a mutant with an insatiable hunger for energy. Moira kept him confined for his own safety as well as others, but when Kevin eventually escaped, his abilities allowed him to warp the very fabric of reality.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-omega-proteus-things-you-didnt-know/\">Omega: 10 Things You Didn't Know About Proteus</a></span></p><p>Proteus is one of the Marvel Universe’s most powerful mutants. His ability to bend reality to his whims makes him extremely dangerous, and capable of just about anything. The Justice League would be hard-pressed to defeat a foe who could transmute coal into kryptonite, or manipulate time and space to ensure the Waynes never went to the movies on that fateful night.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>THE LEAGUE WOULD DEFEAT: THE JUGGERNAUT</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/juggernaut.jpg' /></figure><p>Once Cain Marko, stepbrother of Charles Xavier, gained possession of the Crimson Bands of Cyttorak, he became the unstoppable Juggernaut. As the terrestrial avatar of an extra-dimensional dark god, the Juggernaut is close to invulnerable to conventional attack. However, he’s vulnerable to a psychic barrage when his helmet is removed.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/heroes-juggernaut-fought-won-marvel/\">Raising Cain: 10 Heroes Juggernaut Easily Destroyed</a></span></p><p>It’s entirely possible that the Justice League could defeat the Juggernaut. If enough of the League’s members kept him occupied or immobilized him, the remainder of the team could remove his helmet long enough for the Martian Manhunter to incapacitate him with a psychic attack.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>DEFEAT THE LEAGUE: DARK PHOENIX</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Dark-Phoenix-Greg-Land.jpg' /></figure><p>The Dark Phoenix is an elemental cosmic force, a universal manifestation of life, death, and rebirth. When hosting this force, an individual has<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dark-phoenix-xmen-powers/\"> vast telekinetic and telepathic powers, as well as being able to manipulate matter and energy on a cosmic scale</a>. So powerful is the Phoenix Force that when possessed by it, Jean Grey was able to force a star to go nova, obliterating the planets and civilizations that lived in that solar system.</p><p>In terms of raw power, the Justice League is sorely outmatched in this battle. Even with Superman, Wonder Woman, and the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-green-lantern-ring-weirdest-powers/\">power of a Green Lantern ring</a> behind them, the Phoenix Force could easily and swiftly defeat them. Their only hope would be to somehow reach or influence <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/worst-hosts-phoenix-force/\">the host</a> to combat or reject the power of the Phoenix, and even that would be a gamble!</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>THE LEAGUE WOULD DEFEAT: MR. SINISTER</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Mr-Sinister.jpg' /></figure><p>A 19th century English biologist enthralled with evolutionary theory, Nathanial Essex became obsessed with the burgeoning idea of human mutation. His work caught the eye of Apocalypse, who transformed him into <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/15-creepiest-things-about-mr-sinister/\">Mr. Sinister</a>, an acolyte with the extraordinary powers of super-strength, telekinesis, telepathy, and near immortality.</p><p>Although Mr. Sinister is responsible for some of the worst atrocities against mutantkind in Marvel history, he wouldn’t be able to stand against the might of the entire League. His powers, though impressive, are incapable of overcoming a Kryptonian’s, an Amazon’s, <em>and</em> Martian’s, or even the resourcefulness of a Gotham native!</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/5-characters-justice-league-dark-apokolips-war-did-dirty-5-who-were-written-perfectly/\">5 Characters Justice League Dark: Apokolips War Did Dirty (&#38; 5 Who Were Written Perfectly)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 20:30:31 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/X-Men-Villains-vs-Justice-League.jpg","linkMd5":"92e0c802ccebaf8e7d2a34d9d9db0d02","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn91@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-434_5a80c7d29b8a355d.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":401821,"destBytes":352538,"author":"Julian Beauvais","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/X-Men-Villains-vs-Justice-League.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn91@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-09-434_5a80c7d29b8a355d.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/shadow-king-display.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-24-635_49f496a4a5c043a2.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/X-Men-Magneto-using-powers.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-25-477_1b6c80b7d5bd6f9e.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Cassandra-Nova-in-New-X-Men.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn60@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-23-654_f1c62aa203a38a22.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Apocalypse-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-29-121_fbcb531829de4150.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/vulcan-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-31-158_ba82ef468b33d65b.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Dark-Beast.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-27-149_d106582effa1d844.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Proteus-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn83@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-24-815_f843ba7f5847aa4f.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/juggernaut.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn56@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-29-693_07cd69eec9e231f7.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/Dark-Phoenix-Greg-Land.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn35@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-29-505_965fb8e621ed8295.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Mr-Sinister.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn15@2020_5/2020/08/24/21-43-30-090_3583f72828569b00.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389170},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Dragon Ball Super: The Galactic Patrol Strikes a Major Victory Against Moro's Forces","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-ball-super-galactic-patrol-capture-moro-forces/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-ball-super-galactic-patrol.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </strong></em><strong><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dragon-ball-super/\">Dragon Ball Super</a></strong><em><strong> Chapter 63, by Akira Toriyama, Toyotarou, Caleb Cook and Brandon Bovia, available now in English from Viz Media.</strong></em></p><p>When Moro was first introduced in <em>Dragon Ball Super </em>Chapter 43, the energy-absorbing villain didn't possess the same strength to threaten the universe that he did in the ancient past. This caused the villain to go to New Namek, where he took control of the Dragon Balls and wished himself back to tip-top shape. However, the Namekian Dragon Balls allow for more than just one wish, and Moro's subsequent request was for Porunga to release all of the prisoners held by the Galactic Patrol.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/diary-of-our-days-at-the-breakwater-season-1-episode-7-girls-bonding-time/\">Diary of Our Days at the Breakwater: The Girls Reel in Some Bonding Time</a></span></p><p>These prisoners have generally made up Moro's army and are fierce fighters in their own right, able to wreak a lot of havoc in the name of their master. However, in <em>Dragon Ball Super </em>Chapter 63, their rampage finally comes to an end, even if Moro hasn't yet gone down himself.</p><p>On Earth, Goku and the Z-Fighters have essentially taken down every villain except Moro himself, who is more powerful than ever after absorbing Seven-Three. Using his new powers, Moro was able to defeat the Z-Fighters, but before he could take them down for good, Merus appeared and teleported the heroes away so as to allow Dende to heal them. However, Merus has no intention of defeating Moro. Instead, he's aiming to buy time so that Goku can ascend to the next level and unlock Ultra Instinct for good.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Screen-Shot-2020-08-21-at-10.02.04-PM.png\"/></figure><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/rediscover-how-heavy-are-the-dumbbells-you-lift/\">Now Is the Best Time to Rediscover How Heavy Are the Dumbbells You Lift?</a></span></p><p>Merus and Moro go back and forth, with the former breaking all of the jewels on the latter's body that allows him to copy the abilities of others. However, this starts to wipe Merus from existence, as angels are supposed to remain impartial. Merus reveals that, after working with the Galactic Patrol, he came to believe in justice, and he respected their attempts to bring peace to the universe, despite the fact that they're outmatched in terms of power. Rather, the Galactic Patrol is tenacious and will do what it takes to see justice carried out. After that revelation, the chapter shifts focus to the Galactic Patrol, who reveals that they've caught every escaped convict except for Moro. Galactic Bandit Brigade member Yunba is explicitly shown in handcuffs and a cage to underscore the point. As Merus fades from existence, he asks Goku to protect the universe that he has come to love, making clear that he's sacrificing himself so as to give the Saiyan the push he needs to master Ultra Instinct and defeat Moro once and for all.</p><p>The Galactic Patrol haven't been a particularly useful organization in <em>Dragon Ball Super</em>, due in large part to the fact that they're hopelessly outmatched by both Moro and the Z-Fighters. However, as the \"Galactic Patrol Prisoner Saga\" comes to an end, they've seemingly proven themselves quite useful, as those escaped convicts could have definitely done a lot of damage if allowed to roam free. Plus, they're responsible for inspiring Merus, who is giving Goku the push he needs to become a true defender of the universe. In the end, the Galactic Patrol has proven itself pretty useful, even if it couldn't do much to stop Moro in the first place.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://screenrant.com/dragon-ball-super-future-movies-tv/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Dragon Ball Super</a> Chapter 64 releases Sept. 18.</em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/certain-scientific-railgun-t-episode-19-unlikely-friendship-develops/\">A Certain Scientific Railgun T: An Unlikely Friendship Develops</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 11:45:37 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-ball-super-galactic-patrol.jpg","linkMd5":"941c3e4423c63b5b8219513b7d45c862","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-11-195_47e04e177efc1a81.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":136806,"destBytes":136806,"author":"Liam Nolan","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-ball-super-galactic-patrol.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/24/21-43-11-195_47e04e177efc1a81.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Screen-Shot-2020-08-21-at-10.02.04-PM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-28-980_2896c4637f346db5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389184},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"Haunting of Bly Manor: Hill House's Second Season Debuts Chilling First Photos","link":"https://www.cbr.com/haunting-of-bly-manor-hill-house-second-season-photos/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>Netflix's <em>Haunted</em> series is back with a first look at photos from Mike Flanagan's latest \"literary remix\": <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-haunting-of-bly-manor/\"><em>The Haunting of Bly Manor</em></a>.</p><p><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-haunting-of-hill-house/\">The Haunting of Hill House</a> </em>premiered back in 2018 on Netflix and was met with high regard as a new generation of fans devoured the Shirley Jackson novel turned television series. Flanagan (<em>Doctor Sleep</em>, <em>Gerald’s Game</em>, and <em>Hush</em>) is back with <em>The Haunting of Bly Manor</em>, a follow-up to the original series. Like its predecessor, <em>Bly Manor </em>will tell the story of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/bly-manor-haunting-of-hill-house-season-2/\">another haunted space</a> along with the haunted people that inhabit it. And now, <em><a href=\"https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2020/08/haunting-of-bly-manor-hill-house\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Vanity Fair</a></em> has the first look at the series.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/midnight-club-netflix-adaptation-mike-flanagan/\">Haunting of Hill House Creator to Adapt The Midnight Club for Netflix</a></span></p><p><img src=\"https://media.vanityfair.com/photos/5f40115a476de5b2fc5e5875/master/w_2560%2Cc_limit/The-Haunting-of-Bly-Manor-First-Look-Lede.jpg\" alt=\"Viewer Beware Heres Your First Look at The Haunting of Bly Manor\" /></p><p><img src=\"https://media.vanityfair.com/photos/5f3f4df3ea4a2b0e8b8646ce/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/The-Haunting-of-Bly-Manor-First-Look-Embed06.jpg\" alt=\"Image may contain Human Person Flagstone Footwear Clothing Apparel Shoe Floor Sitting and Flooring\" /></p><p><img src=\"https://media.vanityfair.com/photos/5f3f4fbdf51ed31274cdfcf5/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/The-Haunting-of-Bly-Manor-First-Look-Embed01.jpg\" alt=\"Image may contain Clothing Apparel Human Person Sweater Sleeve Wood and Long Sleeve\" /></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-8.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-9.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-3.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-4.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-5.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-6.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-7.jpg\"/></figure><p>The new series is based on <em>The Turn of the Screw</em> by Henry James, an 1898 novella about a young woman who, along with two orphaned children, moves to the English countryside and encounters ghostly entities. \"It certainly provides a new way to tell a love story, and there are three of them that really beat at the heart of this season,\" Flanagan reveals. \"They all have a very dark edge to them. And by the end, it’s really hard to differentiate tragedy with romance. That sense of romantic longing for someone who meant so much to us—but who’s gone—really is the heart of any ghost story.\"</p><p>Actors from the original <em>Hill</em> <em>House</em> Crain Family<em> </em>are returning to bring the novella to life, including Henry Thomas (Young Hugh Crain), Victoria Pedretti (Nell Crain), Kate Siegel (Theo Crain) and Oliver Jackson-Cohen (Luke Crain). But that may be the only element of familiarity to viewers. Flanagan claims that the two stories are vastly different, both in structure and ambiance. \"Hill House is described by Shirley Jackson as having this gothic, frightening, shadowy presence. Henry James’s Bly Manor, conversely, is described as being bright and sunny and welcoming and rather beautiful.\"</p><p><em>The Haunting of Bly Manor </em>will premiere on Netflix this fall. It is directed by Mike Flanagan and stars Victoria Pedretti, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/haunting-of-hill-house-rahul-kohli/\">Rahul Kohli</a>, Catherine Parker, T'Nia Miller, Amelia Eve, Amelie Smith and Benjamin Ainsworth.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/doctor-sleep-directors-cut-hbo-max/\">Doctor Sleep Director's Cut Is on HBO Max</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 24 Aug 2020 21:29:45 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-header.jpg","linkMd5":"1fe6ea5eb3bb644444a1b8ec230bd9c9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-742_5f8375c68c09db94.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":44611,"destBytes":43870,"author":"Hillary Sussman","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-10-742_5f8375c68c09db94.webp","https://media.vanityfair.com/photos/5f40115a476de5b2fc5e5875/master/w_2560%2Cc_limit/The-Haunting-of-Bly-Manor-First-Look-Lede.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn48@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-25-453_5db6cca34ab94ff3.webp","https://media.vanityfair.com/photos/5f3f4df3ea4a2b0e8b8646ce/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/The-Haunting-of-Bly-Manor-First-Look-Embed06.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn16@2020_3/2020/08/24/21-43-28-453_bee144f6d64bb3ba.webp","https://media.vanityfair.com/photos/5f3f4fbdf51ed31274cdfcf5/master/w_1600%2Cc_limit/The-Haunting-of-Bly-Manor-First-Look-Embed01.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-26-304_2c7b7f6482e42edb.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-23-273_f636b59a777be10b.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn71@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-23-905_8b4d3af5e23b672f.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-21-174_09e27e1b94ff566f.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/24/21-43-21-255_688a6b4d2eaeb59a.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/24/21-43-26-671_e2a0e3935795af6a.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn64@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-24-860_e1fbbe1981e952ca.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/bly-manor-7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn31@2020_2/2020/08/24/21-43-23-550_65fe9935effd36d6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598305389168},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 05:43:09","title":"The Atom Bomb & 9 Other World Events That Superhero Comics Predicted","link":"https://www.cbr.com/atom-bomb-world-events-predicted-marvel-dc-superhero-comics/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Comics-Predict-Future.jpg\"/></figure><p>Comic books are a form of escapist entertainment, allowing readers to forget about the real world and immerse themselves in worlds where anything is possible. Sometimes reality and comics intersect in weird ways, as what happens in the panels of a comic somehow mirror events in the real world. Though a rare occurrence, there have been historical events happen that first appeared on the comic book pages of both<a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/dc/\"> DC</a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvel-comics/\">Marvel</a> comics.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/comics-code-creation-superman-55-other/\">Superman #55 &#38; 9 Other Comics That Led To The Creation Of The Comics Code</a></span></p><p>The following events which run the spectrum from<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-doctor-dooms-incredible-science-magic/\"> scientific discovery</a> to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superheroes-overcoming-personal-tragedy/\">tragedy</a>, all happened in the comics before they actually occurred in the real world. When something like this happens, it is uncanny because comics go through a long process before they are available for purchase. These comics' writers are not clairvoyant but are proof that, sometimes, life imitates art.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>The Atomic Bomb</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-38.jpg' /></figure><p>In 1945, <em>Superman #38</em> saw <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/superman/\">Superman</a>'s arch-nemesis Lex Luthor creating a strange device to carry out his plans to cause chaos in Metropolis. Here, Luthor calls his new invention an \"atomic bomb,\" which in the real world was still being developed by the government, unbeknownst to the writers.</p><p>The Department of Defense found out what the writers were doing and asked DC Comics to delay publishing the issue at a later date. The story goes that the government feared that the Japanese would read the comic and try to build a defense against such a bomb. It was a year later that the world learned of the presence of the atomic bomb. While Luthor's bomb is different from the real one, the government still felt it best to err on the side of caution.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>The Harnessing of Atomic Energy</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Newspaper-strip-1945.jpg' /></figure><p>Using <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-superman-costumes-suits-best-worst/\">Superman </a>as a predictor of inventions during the nuclear age wasn't contained to comic books, but also occurred in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-the-golden-age-newspaper-dailies-1942-1944/\">Superman strips</a> that ran in newspapers. Months after the mention of an atomic bomb in the comics, one of the ongoing storylines in the 1945 Superman newspaper strip featured a skeptical physics professor blasting the Man of Steel with a particle accelerator. This device was referred to as a cyclotron, which was used to test Superman's supposed invulnerability.</p><p>This storyline was published four months before the bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and when the Manhattan Project was at a critical stage. At the time, the US government was censoring anything mentioning atomic energy. The first few installments of this story had already been sent to newspapers across the US by the time the Secret Service contacted the publisher. Even though it was too late to stop the strips, none of the Axis Powers were alerted by the mention of atomic energy.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>The Attack On Pearl Harbor</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Pearl-Harbor-National-Comics.jpg' /></figure><p>Before the United States entered World War II following the bombing of Pearl Harbor, a similar event took place in the pages in <em>National Comics </em>#18. <a href=\"https://www.comicbookresources.com/tag/will+eisner\">Will Eisner</a>, one of the creators who <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/comics-superheroes-patriotic-captain-america/\">showed staunch support of the troops</a> during the war, had Uncle Sam fending off an attack on US soil, including one on Pearl Harbor.</p><p>The issue portraying this attack on the Pacific navel base was published in November of 1941, one month before it really happened. The details in the comic book were different, though, as Eisner wrote a German attack on the Pacific Fleet, not a Japanese one. While the players were different, the timing of this comic hitting stands and its parallels to reality are uncanny.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>The Attack On The World Trade Center (DC)</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Adventures-of-Superman-596-World-Trade-Center.jpg' /></figure><p>September 11, 2001 is a day no one can forget, and one no one could have predicted. It was just by pure circumstance that DC Comics predicted a similar event with <em>The Adventures of Superman #596</em>.
